A significant late season winter storm emerging out of the mid-Mississippi Valley dumped heavy snow over much of western Upper Michigan...especially higher terrain locations along Lake Superior...from the 18th into the 20th.  North winds gusting over 50 mph in the wake of the storm system produced blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured nearly 11 inches of storm total snowfall.  North winds gusting to 30 mph at times caused extensive blowing and drifting of snow on the 19th.  The storm forced the early dismissal of schools on the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant late season winter storm emerging out of the mid-Mississippi Valley dumped heavy snow over much of western Upper Michigan...especially higher terrain locations along Lake Superior...from the 18th into the 20th.  North winds gusting over 50 mph in the wake of the storm system produced blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured eight inches of snow in 28 hours while a spotter northwest of Ishpeming measured over nine inches of snow during the same period.  Northwest winds gusting over 40 mph at times also caused extensive blowing and drifting of snow on the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Newberry measured 4.7 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moist low levels under building high pressure resulted in early morning dense fog over Luce County on the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dense fog reduced visibility to one-quarter mile or less at times at the Newberry AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved through the region during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Strong shear, instability and steep mid level lapse rates all combined with the wave to produce numerous thunderstorms. The storms moved off southern Lake Michigan and continued to expand and intensify as they moved east. Several reports of damaging winds were received along with some hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported a large tree down on near the intersection of Athens and Cline Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of lake effect snow lasted from mid afternoon on February 15th through the late evening hours of the 16th. A dominant lake effect snow band set up across Mason and Oceana counties, where amounts ranged from ten inches to sixteen inches, causing considerable travel difficulties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to sixteen inches of snow fell across Mason county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged Lake Effect Snow Event began late on January 31st with impacts being first felt midday February 1st.  S0me locations saw continuous snow for 72 hours, though the greatest impacts were felt from midday to midnight February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ten to eighteen inches of total snow fell in much of Allegan County. Moderate travel impacts were felt. Some power losses also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged Lake Effect Snow Event began late on January 31st with impacts being first felt midday February 1st.  S0me locations saw continuous snow for 72 hours, though the greatest impacts were felt from midday to midnight February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A foot or more of snow was received during this event. Moderate to high travel impacts were felt across Van Buren County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged Lake Effect Snow Event began late on January 31st with impacts being first felt midday February 1st.  S0me locations saw continuous snow for 72 hours, though the greatest impacts were felt from midday to midnight February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over one foot of snow was received in Ottawa County. Some locations in the western part of the county reported as many as 18 inches total from this snow event. Moderate travel impacts were felt and some power outages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very hot and humid day spawned multiple clusters of strong thunderstorms.  A few became severe, with localized hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed onto homes, and power outages were widespread.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very hot and humid day spawned multiple clusters of strong thunderstorms.  A few became severe, with localized hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple power lines were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very hot and humid day spawned multiple clusters of strong thunderstorms.  A few became severe, with localized hail and strong winds.
A broken line of thunderstorms crossed northern Lake Michigan, producing isolated wind damage in northwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed, one roof had shingles removed, and an awning was ripped off of a camper trailer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long and narrow line of thunderstorms produced isolated wind damage as it crossed eastern Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts to 60 mph were estimated in the Curtis area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept through the region interacting with a strongly sheared, moderately unstable environment. Numerous thunderstorms developed rapidly and produced isolated wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local fire officials reported trees and power lines down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept through the region interacting with a strongly sheared, moderately unstable environment. Numerous thunderstorms developed rapidly and produced isolated wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported a tree of unknown size down onto a garage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front swept through the region interacting with a strongly sheared, moderately unstable environment. Numerous thunderstorms developed rapidly and produced isolated wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a tree down across a road southwest of Bronson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large line of thunderstorms crossed Lake Michigan into northern Lower Michigan during the predawn hours.  These storms produced wind damage in a few spots.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tents were blown down and camper awnings were damaged at the Northwest Michigan Fair.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of showers and thunderstorms impacted places near Lake Michigan.  One storm produced severe hail.
Scattered thunderstorms developed in north central and northeast Lower Michigan in the afternoon and evening of the 16th, along a weak cold front.  Two storms produced marginally large hail.
Scattered thunderstorms developed in north central and northeast Lower Michigan in the afternoon and evening of the 16th, along a weak cold front.  Two storms produced marginally large hail.
A very hot and humid day spawned multiple clusters of strong thunderstorms.  A few became severe, with localized hail and strong winds.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed in the Atlanta area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm with intense lightning dropped heavy rain over the Calumet area on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lightning strike blew holes in the steeple of the Keweenaw Heritage Center at St. Anne's Church in Calumet.  The roofing and underlying wood were shattered.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm with intense lightning dropped heavy rain over the Calumet area on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An automated rain gauge in the Calumet area measured two inches of rain in less than 45 minutes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds out ahead of an approaching cold front gusted to near 50 mph at some locations in Marquette and between 30 and 40 mph across much of the rest of Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of tree limbs down on cars and at least one report of a power line down in Marquette.  A peak wind gust of 44 mph was reported at the K.I Sawyer AWOS station during this same time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Some quarter-sized hail was reported with a lot of pea to dime-sized hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail report near Chatham was received via WLUC-TV Facebook page.  Time of report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny-sized hail was reported near Chatham.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny-sized hail was reported northeast of Iron River.

The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of dime to quarter-sized hail in Trenary.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter near Round Lake reported that two different storms dropped quarter-sized hail.  The first storm passed through around 17:05 EST and the second went through around 17:23 EST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny-sized hail was reported near Iron Mountain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surface trough moving through a very warm and unstable air mass provided the focus for scattered severe thunderstorms over north central Upper Michigan during the early morning of the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer east of Champion reported large trees and branches down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and complex low pressure system lifted toward the southern and western Great Lakes region, bumping into high pressure over northern Ontario and Quebec.  The high helped anchor cold air in place at low levels, while warm and moist air surged in aloft ahead of the low.  This resulted in a wide mix of wintry precipitation, developing on the afternoon of the 11th, and ending late that night.  Eastern Upper Michigan was far enough north to get mostly snow, with up to nine inches measured in Pickford.  In northern Lower, snow transitioned to sleet and freezing rain, and in some places to just rain before dwindling.  Ice amounts were substantial near Saginaw Bay, with 3/4 of an inch of ice in parts of Gladwin County.  Trees and large limbs were downed, and power outages were common.  Another pocket of lighter ice accumulations, around a quarter of an inch, extended from the Grand Traverse Bay region, east to near Gaylord.

Upper disturbances moving through a warm and unstable air mass produced several severe thunderstorms over western Upper Michigan during the late afternoon hours of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down on a power line at the intersection of Sunset Road and Section 16 Road.  The tree was on fire.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning caused a pole barn to catch fire, burning to the ground.  The barn was filled with various tools and machinery, which was destroyed.

A low pressure system originating over the Plains moved across the Upper Great Lakes and brought moderate lake enhanced snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 21st into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Newberry measured 4.7 inches of lake enhanced snow in 24 hours.  There was a public report of 4.5 inches of snow in 20 hours near McMillan.  Several minor accidents were reported due to the wet slushy snow.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated two to four inches of lake enhanced snow fell across the area over a 24-hour period.  Some minor traffic accidents were attributed to the wet slushy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cluster of thunderstorms developed southwest of Chicago during the mid evening hours and moved rapidly east, taking on a bowing structure as it entered southwestern lower Michigan. Wind damage was reported across Berrien county before the line rapidly began weakening as it encountered a more stable air mass.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: County dispatch reported numerous trees down across the southern portions of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense Arctic Front swept through southeast Michigan around Midnight of January 19th, with westerly winds gusting around 60 mph across much of the area during the early morning hours of January 20th. Dozens of trees and power lines were downed across individual counties, leading to power outages in excess of 120,000 DTE customers during the peak of the winds.||Here are some of the higher wind gusts and times reported:||Caro...61 MPH...1214 AM. |Pontiac...60 MPH...301 AM. |Ypsilanti...60 MPH...140 AM.  |Flint...59 MPH...247 AM. |Adrian ...55 MPH...128 AM. |Detroit Metro Airport...55 MPH...158 AM. |White Lake...54 MPH...150 AM. |Owosso...53 MPH...1255 AM. |Downtown Detroit (DET)...53 MPH...149 AM. |Monroe...52 MPH...312 AM. |Lapeer...52 MPH...233 AM.

An Ice Storm affected portions of Southern Lower Michigan from December 21-22.  Ice accumulations of one half to three quarters of an inch occurred across much of Barry, Eaton, Clinton, Ingham, and northern Calhoun and Jackson counties.  ||This resulted in a very prolonged power outage that affected hundreds of thousands of residents across Lower Michigan.  Many people did not have power restored until 4 to 6 days after the ice storm hit.  In addition there was widespread damage in the form of downed trees and tree limbs across the area. A total of 60 million dollars in estimated insured losses occurred across Michigan from this storm with approximately 36 million of this being in SW lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice storm brought a half to three quarters of an inch of ice accumulation across nearly all of the county, causing widespread power outages and downed trees, tree limbs and lines.  At one point over 20,000 people were without power in Barry county alone, and thousands of people did not have power restored until 5 to 6 days after the storm hit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Ice Storm affected portions of Southern Lower Michigan from December 21-22.  Ice accumulations of one half to three quarters of an inch occurred across much of Barry, Eaton, Clinton, Ingham, and northern Calhoun and Jackson counties.  ||This resulted in a very prolonged power outage that affected hundreds of thousands of residents across Lower Michigan.  Many people did not have power restored until 4 to 6 days after the ice storm hit.  In addition there was widespread damage in the form of downed trees and tree limbs across the area. A total of 60 million dollars in estimated insured losses occurred across Michigan from this storm with approximately 36 million of this being in SW lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A half to three quarters of an inch of ice accumulation occurred across nearly all of Ingham county, causing widespread power outages and downed trees, tree limbs and lines. Thousands of people did not have power restored until 5 to 6 days after the storm hit.

A low pressure system moving through the Lower Great Lakes brought moderate snow to portions of south central Upper Michigan on the 22nd.  Colder air in the wake of this system resulted in moderate to heavy lake effect snow from the 22nd into the 24th over the higher terrain of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report from Gourley Township of an estimated four to five inches of snow in eight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Ice Storm affected portions of Southern Lower Michigan from December 21-22.  Ice accumulations of one half to three quarters of an inch occurred across much of Barry, Eaton, Clinton, Ingham, and northern Calhoun and Jackson counties.  ||This resulted in a very prolonged power outage that affected hundreds of thousands of residents across Lower Michigan.  Many people did not have power restored until 4 to 6 days after the ice storm hit.  In addition there was widespread damage in the form of downed trees and tree limbs across the area. A total of 60 million dollars in estimated insured losses occurred across Michigan from this storm with approximately 36 million of this being in SW lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice storm brought a half an inch of ice accumulation across southern Clinton county, causing numerous power outages and downed trees, tree limbs and lines. Thousands of people did not have power restored until 3 to 5 days after the storm hit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow occurred December 23rd into the early morning hours of the 24th near Lake Michigan, particularly west of Grand Rapids from near Saugatuck north to Muskegon and Newaygo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to 18 inches was measured one mile south southwest of Holton, with 17.5 inches at Twin Lake and 17 inches reported at Lakewood Club. 12 inches or more was experienced across most of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow occurred December 23rd into the early morning hours of the 24th near Lake Michigan, particularly west of Grand Rapids from near Saugatuck north to Muskegon and Newaygo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to around 8 inches of snow fell, with heaviest amounts near Grand Haven over extreme northwest Ottawa county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow occurred December 23rd into the early morning hours of the 24th near Lake Michigan, particularly west of Grand Rapids from near Saugatuck north to Muskegon and Newaygo.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over 8 inches of snow was reported in Fremont, with heaviest lake effect snow impacting southwestern Newaygo county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm impacted a large swath of the country from the southern Plains through the Midwest and into the Northeast on the last weekend before Christmas.  This storm occurred as a deep upper-level trough over the Desert Southwest lifted northeastward, while a surface low pressure system moved from Texas into the Ohio Valley.  This low moved along a very sharp frontal boundary.  This front at the surface actually briefly penetrated far southeastern Michigan Friday night.  The temperature at Lambertville, on the Ohio border, rose into the mid-50s, while Monroe, just 15 miles away, stayed in the mid-30s.  On Saturday, copious Gulf moisture was brought northward ahead of the approaching surface low.  This warm, moist air was forced to ascend at the front over Ohio, spreading precipitation from south to north over southeast Michigan from the late morning into the afternoon.  An anticyclone over Ontario provided a supply of low-level cold air, causing the surface temperature to be near or below freezing for much of southeast Michigan.  The result was a swath of freezing rain roughly between M-59 to M-46 which continued into Saturday night and early Sunday.  The I-69 corridor was especially hard-hit, with ice accumulations of half an inch to three quarters of an inch, causing over 200,000 homes and businesses to lose power.  Numerous trees and wires were downed, and a state of emergency was declared in Shiawassee County due to unsafe traveling conditions.  South of M-59, much of the precipitation occurred as rain, with some locations receiving over 1.50 rain.  North of M-46, much of the precipitation occurred as snow, with up to 4 inches reported.

Cold air flowing across Lake Michigan ahead of low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy enhanced snow to east central Upper Michigan from late on the 24th into the 25th.  A strong west to northwest flow of cold air behind this trough passage also brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow to portions of west and northeast Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 8.5 inches of lake enhanced snow in 12 hours at Newberry with nearly a foot of snow reported near Dollarville in 15 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air in the wake of a low pressure system moving through the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow over the Keweenaw Peninsula and over northern Luce County from the 9th into the 12th.  Wind chill values also lowered to 25 to 30 below zero for various locations from the 11th into 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Ahmeek measured nine inches of lake effect snow in seven hours.  The observer in Mohawk measured seven inches of snow in the 12-hour period ending in the early evening of the 9th.  Extensive blowing and drifting of snow and occasional visibility less than one-quarter mile was also reported by the Mohawk observer.

Wind chill values also lowered to 25 to 30 below zero for various locations from the 11th into 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer four miles northeast of Calumet measured seven inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours along with considerable blowing and drifting of snow and reduced visibility.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Parent Bay to Thompson and Manistique measured five to six inches of snow in approximately seven hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm impacted a large swath of the country from the southern Plains through the Midwest and into the Northeast on the last weekend before Christmas.  This storm occurred as a deep upper-level trough over the Desert Southwest lifted northeastward, while a surface low pressure system moved from Texas into the Ohio Valley.  This low moved along a very sharp frontal boundary.  This front at the surface actually briefly penetrated far southeastern Michigan Friday night.  The temperature at Lambertville, on the Ohio border, rose into the mid-50s, while Monroe, just 15 miles away, stayed in the mid-30s.  On Saturday, copious Gulf moisture was brought northward ahead of the approaching surface low.  This warm, moist air was forced to ascend at the front over Ohio, spreading precipitation from south to north over southeast Michigan from the late morning into the afternoon.  An anticyclone over Ontario provided a supply of low-level cold air, causing the surface temperature to be near or below freezing for much of southeast Michigan.  The result was a swath of freezing rain roughly between M-59 to M-46 which continued into Saturday night and early Sunday.  The I-69 corridor was especially hard-hit, with ice accumulations of half an inch to three quarters of an inch, causing over 200,000 homes and businesses to lose power.  Numerous trees and wires were downed, and a state of emergency was declared in Shiawassee County due to unsafe traveling conditions.  South of M-59, much of the precipitation occurred as rain, with some locations receiving over 1.50 rain.  North of M-46, much of the precipitation occurred as snow, with up to 4 inches reported.
Light freezing rain spread north into the region ahead of a warm front during the evening hours of January 27th. Ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of snow, sleet, and freezing rain changed over to all freezing rain during the evening hours of January 27th. Ice accretions were generally near a tenth of an inch, while snow and sleet accumulations ranged between a dusting and 1 inch. Roads became slick and hazardous which resulted in a few accidents across southern Michigan. The freezing rain changed over to rain and drizzle during the early morning hours of January 28th as temperatures warmed above freezing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Iron Mountain measured 3.8 inches of snow in 24 hours.  Along with the snow, The Iron Mountain ASOS reported nearly seven hours of freezing rain during the late morning and afternoon of the 4th.   Several accidents were reported throughout the area and lingering effects from the icy roads caused school delays or closures into the 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer five miles southeast of Watersmeet measured nearly four inches of wet snow in less than 24 hours.  The observer near Bergland reported sleet and freezing rain for several hours on the afternoon of the 4th.  Several accidents were reported throughout the area due to slippery highways.  Lingering effects from the icy roads forced the closure of Watersmeet Schools on the 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread four to five inches of snow fell in just under 24 hours.  On top of the snow, freezing rain accumulated up to .2 inch in 4-5 hours on the afternoon of the 4th.  Numerous accidents were reported throughout the area.  Lingering effects from the icy roads forced the closure of many schools throughout the county on the 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread four to five inches of wet snow fell in less than 24 hours throughout Baraga County.  Several hours of sleet and freezing rain were also reported on the afternoon of the 4th resulting in several accidents.  Lingering effects from the icy roads forced the closure of many schools throughout the county on the 5th.

Cold air flowing across Lake Michigan ahead of low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy enhanced snow to east central Upper Michigan from late on the 24th into the 25th.  A strong west to northwest flow of cold air behind this trough passage also brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow to portions of west and northeast Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread three to four inches of lake enhanced snow occurred across southern Schoolcraft County in 12 hours at Manistique.  Most of this snow fell between 5 am and 9 am on the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three inches of snow accumulated in less than 24 hours over portions of Alger County.  On top of the snow accumulation, up to .2 inch of freezing rain accumulated in about five hours on the afternoon of the 4th.  Numerous accidents were reported throughout the area, and the lingering effects from the icy roads forced the closure of many schools throughout the county on the 5th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder Arctic air moving in behind a departing low pressure system produced heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula and over Alger County from the 5th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Redridge estimated nine inches of lake effect snow and blowing over 12 hours on the 5th and measured a storm total snowfall of 12 inches through the morning of the 6th.  West winds 20 to 30 mph with gusts to 45 mph caused considerable blowing of snow between Atlantic Mine and Houghton on the 5th with near zero visibility at times.  The heavy snow and blowing snow forced the closure of many schools throughout the county on the 5th and two-hour delay of schools on the 6th.

Further inland snowfall amounts were much lighter but still amounted to 1 to 3 inches along the Interstate 69 corridor.||Here are the following locations which reported 8 inches of snow in 6 hours:|In Sanilac County...|Port Sanilac (1N)...Forestville (2S)...Croswell (5ENE)...Lexington (5S). ||In St. Clair County...Smiths Creek (2N).

Cold air flowing across Lake Michigan ahead of low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy enhanced snow to east central Upper Michigan from late on the 24th into the 25th.  A strong west to northwest flow of cold air behind this trough passage also brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow to portions of west and northeast Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Garden Corners measured 3.5 inches of lake enhanced snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air flowing across Lake Michigan ahead of low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy enhanced snow to east central Upper Michigan from late on the 24th into the 25th.  A strong west to northwest flow of cold air behind this trough passage also brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow to portions of west and northeast Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report near Redridge of eight inches of lake effect snow in six hours with near zero visibility in snow and blowing snow.  Five inches of snow fell in Calumet in less than three hours during the early afternoon of the 26th, and nearly seven inches fell near South Range in less than 16 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured from four to five inches of lake effect snow over mainly the northern portion of the county from late evening on the 26th through mid morning of the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mesoscale low pressure systems generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow  over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Garden measured 12 inches of lake enhanced snow in about 6 hours from mesoscale low pressure system over northern Lake Michigan.  The heavy snow and near zero visibility at times caused problems especially along Highway US-2 for Thanksgiving day travelers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mesoscale low pressure systems generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow  over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Parent Bay measured 11 inches of lake enhanced snow in six hours.  The heavy snow and near zero visibility at times caused problems for Thanksgiving day travelers on Highway US-2 between Garden Corners and Manistique.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Mesoscale low pressure systems generated moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow  over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of seven inches of lake enhanced snow near L'anse on the evening of the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of light to moderate rain moving north through Wisconsin produced light freezing rain across portions of west and central Upper Michigan late evening on the 10th into the early morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain created icy conditions especially over the higher terrain of western Marquette county.  Icy roads were reported from Champion through Republic to Witch Lake over Highways US-41 and M-95. NICE Community and Republic-Michigamme schools were closed due to icy roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of light to moderate rain moving north through Wisconsin produced light freezing rain across portions of west and central Upper Michigan late evening on the 10th into the early morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain was reported in Iron River.  Crystal Falls, Forest River and Florence schools were closed due to icy roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of light to moderate rain moving north through Wisconsin produced light freezing rain across portions of west and central Upper Michigan late evening on the 10th into the early morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow-packed side roads in the Bessemer area were reportedly icy due to light freezing rain.  Watersmeet Schools were closed due to icy roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of light to moderate rain moving north through Wisconsin produced light freezing rain across portions of west and central Upper Michigan late evening on the 10th into the early morning of the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light freezing rain was reported from Norway to Iron Mountain producing slick spots on cement surfaces and roadways.  Highway M-95 was reported to be ice-covered and slippery.  North Dickinson Schools were closed and schools in the Iron Mountain-Norway area were on a two-hour delay due to icy roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved through the Ohio Valley on Saturday, spreading a swath of snow over Southeast Michigan. Totals were greatest toward the Ohio Border and Erie Shoreline where 8+ inches were reported. The snow was mainly light to moderate, but occurred over a long duration of 20-24 hours, which allowed the snow to accumulate.|Here are some of the higher accumulations reported:|Newport...9.4 inches.|Morenci...8.7 inches.|Wyandotte...8.4 inches.|Carleton...8.2 inches.|Detroit Metro Airport...7.7 inches.

A six day heat impacted Southeast Michigan July 14th through the 19th with high temperatures ranging from the upper 80s to mid 90s. Heat Indices were in the 90s for the most part, but Detroit Metro area hospitals reported an increase of 173 heat related illnesses during this stretch.  Here are the daily maxes reported at Flint Bishop Airport and Detroit Metro Airport during the six days.|Flint: 90, 93, 94, 95, 95, 96.|Detroit: 89, 93, 90, 94, 94, 95.

An Ice Storm affected portions of Southern Lower Michigan from December 21-22.  Ice accumulations of one half to three quarters of an inch occurred across much of Barry, Eaton, Clinton, Ingham, and northern Calhoun and Jackson counties.  ||This resulted in a very prolonged power outage that affected hundreds of thousands of residents across Lower Michigan.  Many people did not have power restored until 4 to 6 days after the ice storm hit.  In addition there was widespread damage in the form of downed trees and tree limbs across the area. A total of 60 million dollars in estimated insured losses occurred across Michigan from this storm with approximately 36 million of this being in SW lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to one-half an inch of ice accumulation occurred across southern Ionia county, causing numerous power outages and downed trees, tree limbs and lines. Thousands of people did not have power restored until 3 to 5 days after the storm hit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Ice Storm affected portions of Southern Lower Michigan from December 21-22.  Ice accumulations of one half to three quarters of an inch occurred across much of Barry, Eaton, Clinton, Ingham, and northern Calhoun and Jackson counties.  ||This resulted in a very prolonged power outage that affected hundreds of thousands of residents across Lower Michigan.  Many people did not have power restored until 4 to 6 days after the ice storm hit.  In addition there was widespread damage in the form of downed trees and tree limbs across the area. A total of 60 million dollars in estimated insured losses occurred across Michigan from this storm with approximately 36 million of this being in SW lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice storm brought a third to over a half an inch of ice accumulation to the eastern third of Allegan county, causing numerous power outages and downed tree limbs and lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A winter storm impacted a large swath of the country from the southern Plains through the Midwest and into the Northeast on the last weekend before Christmas.  This storm occurred as a deep upper-level trough over the Desert Southwest lifted northeastward, while a surface low pressure system moved from Texas into the Ohio Valley.  This low moved along a very sharp frontal boundary.  This front at the surface actually briefly penetrated far southeastern Michigan Friday night.  The temperature at Lambertville, on the Ohio border, rose into the mid-50s, while Monroe, just 15 miles away, stayed in the mid-30s.  On Saturday, copious Gulf moisture was brought northward ahead of the approaching surface low.  This warm, moist air was forced to ascend at the front over Ohio, spreading precipitation from south to north over southeast Michigan from the late morning into the afternoon.  An anticyclone over Ontario provided a supply of low-level cold air, causing the surface temperature to be near or below freezing for much of southeast Michigan.  The result was a swath of freezing rain roughly between M-59 to M-46 which continued into Saturday night and early Sunday.  The I-69 corridor was especially hard-hit, with ice accumulations of half an inch to three quarters of an inch, causing over 200,000 homes and businesses to lose power.  Numerous trees and wires were downed, and a state of emergency was declared in Shiawassee County due to unsafe traveling conditions.  South of M-59, much of the precipitation occurred as rain, with some locations receiving over 1.50 rain.  North of M-46, much of the precipitation occurred as snow, with up to 4 inches reported.

A low pressure system moved through the Ohio Valley on Saturday, spreading a swath of snow over Southeast Michigan. Totals were greatest toward the Ohio Border and Erie Shoreline where 8+ inches were reported. The snow was mainly light to moderate, but occurred over a long duration of 20-24 hours, which allowed the snow to accumulate.|Here are some of the higher accumulations reported:|Newport...9.4 inches.|Morenci...8.7 inches.|Wyandotte...8.4 inches.|Carleton...8.2 inches.|Detroit Metro Airport...7.7 inches.

Ice accumulations of one half to three quarters of an inch occurred across much of Barry, Eaton, Clinton, Ingham, and northern Calhoun and Jackson counties.  ||This resulted in a very prolonged power outage that affected hundreds of thousands of residents across Lower Michigan.  Many people did not have power restored until 4 to 6 days after the ice storm hit.  In addition there was widespread damage in the form of downed trees and tree limbs across the area. A total of 60 million dollars in estimated insured losses occurred across Michigan from this storm with approximately 36 million of this being in SW lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice storm brought a half an inch of ice accumulation across far southern Kent county.  Over 30,000 people in Kent county lost power.

Some sleet and freezing rain mixed with snow on the afternoon of the 4th.  Numerous accidents were reported throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Relief from a 6 day Heat Wave came in the form of a slow moving cold front, which triggered multiple rounds of severe thunderstorms across Southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of July 19th.

Relief from a 6 day Heat Wave came in the form of a slow moving cold front, which triggered multiple rounds of severe thunderstorms across Southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of July 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Houghton County Airport measured a west wind gust to 59 mph on the morning of the 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak area of low pressure moved east-northeast from the central plains, crossing northern lower Michigan on the 9th. Most of the snow was not heavy, but southeast winds off of Lake Huron resulted in lake enhanced snowfall in far southeast upper Michigan. Six to twelve inches of snowfall was common east of I-75 and south of Pickford, with an isolated report of 17 inches near the Chippewa/Mackinac county line near Lake Huron.

Weak west-northwest winds resulted in somewhat disorganized, but intense, lake effect snow in parts of northern Michigan. Snowfall rates exceeded two inches per hour at times. The NWS office near Gaylord picked up 16 inches of snow on the 15th, setting a new all-time record for a single calendar day. Eighteen inches fell a little west of the office, in eastern Antrim County. Meanwhile, a snowband of Lake Superior origin was enhanced as it crossed northern Lake Huron. This band impacted the Presque Isle County coast, with Rogers City picking up around a foot of new snow.

Weak west-northwest winds resulted in somewhat disorganized, but intense, lake effect snow in parts of northern Michigan. Snowfall rates exceeded two inches per hour at times. The NWS office near Gaylord picked up 16 inches of snow on the 15th, setting a new all-time record for a single calendar day. Eighteen inches fell a little west of the office, in eastern Antrim County. Meanwhile, a snowband of Lake Superior origin was enhanced as it crossed northern Lake Huron. This band impacted the Presque Isle County coast, with Rogers City picking up around a foot of new snow.

The coldest air of the season thus far surged into the region on north-northwest winds. Substantial lake effect snow resulting in northwest Lower Michigan, during the daylight and evening hours of the 23rd.  Six to ten inches of snow were common in central Leelanau, eastern Grand Traverse, western Kalkaska, and northwest Missaukee Counties. Fife Lake picked up the most snow, 10 inches.
An upper disturbance approaching from Minnesota produced moderate snow over portions of west and south central Upper Michigan on the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Ironwood measured 3.2 inches of snow in 7 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance approaching from Minnesota produced moderate snow over portions of west and south central Upper Michigan on the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Amasa and Caspian measured three inches of snow in 6 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong south winds ahead of an approaching cold front produced damage in Carney on the evening of the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Non-convective winds associated with a line of showers snapped a 14-inch diameter 30 foot tall pine tree and blew a trampoline across a yard in Carney.  The time of the report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds in the wake of cold front produced moderate lake effect snow showers over portions of west and east central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th to the morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Van Meer and Melstrand measured between 5 and 6 inches of lake effect snow in approximately 18 hours.  Slippery roads contributed to several minor traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds in the wake of cold front produced moderate lake effect snow showers over portions of west and east central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th to the morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Newberry measured 6.1 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.  Slippery roads contributed to several minor traffic accidents.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Garden Corners measured 2.8 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours. Slippery roads contributed to several minor traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system tracking through the Great Lakes generated strong northwest winds across the region and some moderate snow downwind of Lake Superior from the evening of the 17th through the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds knocked down several trees and caused power outages to more than 1,000 Upper Peninsula Power customers across the area.  Ishpeming Public Schools closed its middle/high school complex due to loss of power.  At St. Johns Parish an early childhood program and a nursing class were cancelled.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful storm system tracking through the Great Lakes generated strong northwest winds across the region and some moderate snow downwind of Lake Superior from the evening of the 17th through the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Grand Marais GLOS measured a peak wind gust of 65 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak west-northwest winds resulted in somewhat disorganized, but intense, lake effect snow in parts of northern Michigan. Snowfall rates exceeded two inches per hour at times. The NWS office near Gaylord picked up 16 inches of snow on the 15th, setting a new all-time record for a single calendar day. Eighteen inches fell a little west of the office, in eastern Antrim County. Meanwhile, a snowband of Lake Superior origin was enhanced as it crossed northern Lake Huron. This band impacted the Presque Isle County coast, with Rogers City picking up around a foot of new snow.

Low pressure moved across the southern Great Lakes late on the 22nd. Snow develpoed ahead of, and north of, the track of the low. This snow was not heavy in most of the area, but a narrow band of heavier snow did fall in the Straits of Mackinac region. Ten to twelve inches of snow fell in St Igance, Goetzville, Bliss, and Onaway.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 15 miles south of Wetmore measured four inches of lake effect snow in eight hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Watton measured three inches of snow in 15 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front generated moderate lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior from the 22nd into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ewen received over three inches of lake effect snow in less than 10 hours while Paulding measured nearly four inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front generated moderate lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior from the 22nd into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Ironwood measured 3.1 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front generated moderate lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior from the 22nd into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of an estimated five inches of lake effect snow in six hours near Tamarack Lake in far eastern Gogebic County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front generated moderate lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior from the 22nd into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Parent Bay measured seven inches of lake effect snow in 36 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 7.5 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours at Nisula.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 3.7 inches of lake effect snow in L'anse over 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Eben Junction measured four inches of lake effect snow in three hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance approaching from Minnesota produced moderate snow over portions of west and south central Upper Michigan on the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Bark River measured 3.5 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spilling into the region allowed for dangerously cold wind chills to occur over Gogebic County from the evening of the 7th into the morning of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS in Ironwood measured wind chills of 25 to 30 below from the evening of the 7th into the early morning of the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north flow of colder air across Lake Superior brought moderate lake effect snow to portions of Baraga and Marquette counties from the 19th into the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 5.5 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours in L'anse.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spreading into the area from the west-northwest along with winds around 10 mph caused wind chills to plummet into 25 to 35 below zero range at times over southwest Upper Michigan from the evening of the 29th into the evening of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell into the 25 to 35 below range throughout much of the period for locations well away from Lake Superior.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spreading into the area from the west-northwest along with winds around 10 mph caused wind chills to plummet into 25 to 35 below zero range at times over southwest Upper Michigan from the evening of the 29th into the evening of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell into the 25 to 35 below range throughout much of the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 10 miles south of Grand Marais measured 6.5 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Watton measured 4.5 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Herman measured 6.8 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: More cold air crossing Lake Superior produced moderate to heavy lake effect snow for the west to northwest snow belts from the 25th into the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 5.8 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A north flow of colder air across Lake Superior brought moderate lake effect snow to portions of Baraga and Marquette counties from the 19th into the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous 24-hour snowfall amounts fell in the 5 to 8 inch range over the higher terrain of Marquette County and especially the western half of the county.  The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 8.1 inches over 24 hours with most of the lake effect snow falling on the morning of the 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much colder air in the wake of an Arctic cold front produced moderate snow and blowing snow over portions of northwest and north central Upper Michigan from the 28th into the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured 3.3 inches of lake effect snow in the 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 29th.  Six hours of light freezing rain accumulated up to an eighth of inch before the snow started on the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much colder air in the wake of an Arctic cold front produced moderate snow and blowing snow over portions of northwest and north central Upper Michigan from the 28th into the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Houghton measured five inches of lake effect snow in approximately 18 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Much colder air in the wake of an Arctic cold front produced moderate snow and blowing snow over portions of northwest and north central Upper Michigan from the 28th into the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread one to two inches of lake effect snow occurred in approximately a six-hour period.  North winds gusting over 30 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of the fine snowflakes causing whiteout conditions at times.  The Alger County Sheriff's Office reported several accidents on Highway M-28 just west of Munising due to whiteout conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A continued flow of Arctic air across Lake Superior allowed moderate to heavy lake effect snow to develop over the west to northwest wind snow belts of the Keweenaw Peninsula from the 30th into the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of heavy lake effect snow in the Calumet area with over one-inch per hour snowfall rates recorded during the afternoon of the 30th.  One report of total snowfall measured 14 inches over a 19-hour period ending on the morning of the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A continued flow of Arctic air across Lake Superior allowed moderate to heavy lake effect snow to develop over the west to northwest wind snow belts of the Keweenaw Peninsula from the 30th into the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total lake effect snowfall over a 24-hour period included eight inches at Mohawk and nine inches at Ahmeek.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air spreading into the area from the west-northwest along with winds around 10 mph caused wind chills to plummet into 25 to 35 below zero range at times over southwest Upper Michigan from the evening of the 29th into the evening of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell into the 25 to 35 below range throughout much of the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to four inches of wet snow fell in approximately nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer five miles west of Watton measured 4.3 inches of wet snow in nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Ironwood measured 13 inches of storm total snowfall in 30 hours.  Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and reduced visibility.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured 4.7 inches of snow in 14 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Sidnaw measured nearly six inches of wet snow in approximately 13 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured a storm total snowfall of 29.2 inches over 60 hours and recorded a snow depth of 62 inches on the morning of the 21st.  The spotter in Munising measured 20 inches of storm total snowfall.  Northwest winds gusting to 35 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and occasional whiteout conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening low pressure system tracking east through the Ohio Valley region dropped between 6 and 12 inches of heavy snow on southwest Lower Michigan, mainly during the afternoon and evening hours of March 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the area during the afternoon hours of March 5th and became heavy at times during the evening and early overnight hours. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 5 and 9 inches, heaviest across southwestern portions of the county. There was a report of 7.0 inches in Twelve Mile. The intensity of the heavy snow and sub-freezing surface temperatures allowed the snow to accumulate on roadways. This resulted in hazardous travel conditions across the region with numerous school closings the morning of March 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather struck portions of Southwest Lower Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of May 20th.  Damaging winds and large hail accompanied the strongest storms.  As the temperature and humidity levels climbed through the day, this led to a very unstable airmass in Michigan.  The arrival of a wave of low pressure triggered the storms shortly after noon.  As this feature tracked northeastward through Lower Michigan through the afternoon and evening, the storms strengthened and expanded in coverage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A one and three quarters inch diameter hail report was relayed by WZZM-TV 13 near Rodney.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across the region generated moderate lake effect snow showers which affected Alger and Luce counties on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Melstrand estimated six inches of lake effect snow into the early afternoon of the 1st while Grand Marais measured five inches of snow.  Northwest winds gusting near 30 mph also caused blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across the region generated moderate lake effect snow showers which affected Alger and Luce counties on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Newberry measured 5.2 inches of lake effect snow through the early morning hours of the 1st.  Northwest winds gusting to 25 mph also caused some blowing and drifting of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving in the Northern Plains produced moderate snow over portions of northwest Upper Michigan from the 6th into the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter report from Laurium measured 8.5 inches of snow in approximately 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving in the Northern Plains produced moderate snow over portions of northwest Upper Michigan from the 6th into the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured 6.8 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread reports from Menominee to Powers measured nearly five inches of wet snow during the event.  Precipitation starting off as a mixture of sleet and freezing rain on the evening of the 11th.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 12th due to the heavy wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals over approximately a 12-hour period included 8.5 inches at Van Meer, 6.7 inches near Munising and six inches at Chatham.  The snow was reportedly very wet and heavy.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ironwood measured 11 inches of wet snow over a two-day period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated seven inches over northern Schoolcraft County in a 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 19th.  Additional accumulation of lake effect snow continued into the morning of the 21st.  The additional snowfall combined with northwest winds gusting to 35 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and reduced visibility into the morning of the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters throughout the county measured five to six inches of snow over a 14-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Amasa measured five inches of wet snow in 17 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Norway measured 4.7 inches of wet snow in 16 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters from Menominee to Stephenson measured five to six inches of wet snow in 17 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Norway measured five inches of wet snow in 12 hours.  Four to six inches of wet snow fell in the Iron Mountain area in less than 24 hours.  Schools were closed throughout the county due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifting through the region brought a period of snow, sleet, and freezing drizzle to southern Michigan during the early morning hours of February 22.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the area during the early morning hours of February 22nd before ending as a brief period of freezing drizzle. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 2 and 3 inches. Ice accretions were less than 0.05 inches. Temperatures in the 20s allowed the light snow and ice to accumulate on area roadways. This led to a few accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Ishpeming measured nearly six inches of wet snow in a 16-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Parent Bay measured five inches of wet snow over a 17-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the region brought brief moderate snow to portions of central Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Iron Mountain and Norway measured between three and four inches of wet snow over a four-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front stalling over a warm and humid air mass helped generate some strong thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of Gogebic County on the morning of the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Marenisco measured 4.11 inches of rainfall in the early morning of the 7th.  Most of the rain fell over a six-hour period.  Near Bessemer, a spotter measured 2.23 inches over approximately the same period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough deepening over the Great Lakes generated thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th. Some of the storms turned severe over Gogebic and Dickinson counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were reported down around the Felch area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough deepening over the Great Lakes generated thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th. Some of the storms turned severe over Gogebic and Dickinson counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Funnel cloud was spotted just north of U.S. Highways 2 and 41 and was headed east.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving, occluded low pressure system was nearly parked across the far northern Great Lakes.  A light synoptic snowfall gave way to more substantial lake effect snow during the day on the 19th.  By evening, snowfall totals were around a foot in areas just west of Traverse City (including Lake Ann, Leland, Interlochen, and Brethren).  Meanwhile, 6 to 8 inches of snow fell in the lake effect snow belts from Petoskey, to East Jordan, to near Gaylord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough deepening over the Great Lakes generated thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th. Some of the storms turned severe over Gogebic and Dickinson counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nearly four inches of rain caused minor flash flooding in Foster City on the evening of the 25th.  Cunard Road in Foster City was washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough deepening over the Great Lakes generated thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th. Some of the storms turned severe over Gogebic and Dickinson counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of over six inches of rainfall near McMillan in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper disturbance moving through the area generated a severe thunderstorm with large hail at Melstrand on the afternoon of the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Melstrand observed one-inch diameter hail.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic high pressure would move off to the east late on the 6th.  Light snow developed late at night on the 6th, as warmer air tried to work north into the region.  Much heavier snow got going on the afternoon and evening of the 7th, as low pressure crossed northwest Ohio and southeast Lower Michigan.  By morning on the 8th, snowfall amounts topped out at around 10 inches in the Gladwin, Tawas, and Standish areas.

Strong and cold northwest winds surged into northern Michigan on the evening of the 19th, as low pressure crossing Upper Michigan pushed a cold front across the region. The front itself brought intense snow showers, some producing thunder and lightning. Lake effect snow cranked up behind the front, along with wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph. By morning of the 20th, snowfall amounts ranged from 3 to 6 inches in much of Chippewa County in eastern Upper Michigan, as well as in the Boyne Falls and Elmira areas of northern Lower Michigan. Considerable blowing and drifting snow occurred as well.

As this feature tracked northeastward through Lower Michigan through the afternoon and evening, the storms strengthened and expanded in coverage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ingham county dispatch reported downed trees and power lines near Williamston.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few reports of damaging wind gusts and large hail were received on May 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nickel sized hail was reported near Newaygo.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few reports of damaging wind gusts and large hail were received on May 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Clinton county emergency manager reported that two relatively new barns were blown down by wind gusts of around 70 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from Minnesota produced a mix of moderate wet snow, sleet and freezing rain over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread two to four inches of wet snow occurred throughout the county during the evening of the 14th before the precipitation changed over to rain and freezing rain early on the 15th.  The observer near Pelkie reported branches broken off of white pine tree on property due to ice accumulation.  The mixed precipitation forced a two-hour delay at many area schools on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from Minnesota produced a mix of moderate wet snow, sleet and freezing rain over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of an estimated 4.5 inches of heavy wet snow and sleet near Big Bay during the evening of the 14th.  The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 2.7 inches of wet snow along with a tenth of an inch of ice accumulation from freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant late season winter storm emerging out of the mid-Mississippi Valley dumped heavy snow over much of western Upper Michigan...especially higher terrain locations along Lake Superior...from the 18th into the 20th.  North winds gusting over 50 mph in the wake of the storm system produced blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow and extensive blowing snow was reported from Eagle Harbor to near Calumet as north winds gusted near 45 mph at times.  Six inches of snow was reported at Eagle Harbor in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic high pressure would move off to the east late on the 6th.  Light snow developed late at night on the 6th, as warmer air tried to work north into the region.  Much heavier snow got going on the afternoon and evening of the 7th, as low pressure crossed northwest Ohio and southeast Lower Michigan.  By morning on the 8th, snowfall amounts topped out at around 10 inches in the Gladwin, Tawas, and Standish areas.

A series of small, weak, lake-generated low pressure systems moved southeast into northwest Lower Michigan, primarily on the night of the 15th into the 16th.  These generated briefly heavy lake effect snow squalls, from Suttons Bay southward to Brethren and Wellston.  Snowfall amounts of 6 to 8 inches were common in those coastal counties.

Very cold, but relatively light, northwest winds brought lake effect snow to northern Michigan.  An isolated area of heavy snow occurred in the Paradise area of eastern Upper Michigan, where around 9 inches of snow fell on the 21st.  Snowfall amounts were a little less in northern Lower Michigan, where 4 to 8 inches fell in parts of the snowbelts over a 24-hour period.
A teenage boy was carried offshore by a structural rip current at Aronson Island in Escanaba, and then he was overcome by the crashing of 3-4 foot waves.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Coast Guard confirmed that a teenage boy drowned on the afternoon of the 17th in a structural rip current at Aronson Island in Escanaba.  He was carried offshore by the rip current and then was overcome by the crashing of 3-4 foot waves.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A series of small, weak, lake-generated low pressure systems moved southeast into northwest Lower Michigan, primarily on the night of the 15th into the 16th.  These generated briefly heavy lake effect snow squalls, from Suttons Bay southward to Brethren and Wellston.  Snowfall amounts of 6 to 8 inches were common in those coastal counties.

Low pressure would lift northeastward across northern Lower Michigan in the early morning hours of the 19th.  Out ahead of the system, precipitation fell as snow in eastern Upper Michigan, and as a mix to the south, though this precipitation was relatively light.  As the system departed, strong winds brought in much colder air and accumulating lake effect snow by afternoon on the 19th.  Snow amounts pushed 10 inches at Sault Ste Marie, and ranged from 5 to 8 inches across much of northwest Lower Michigan.  The strong winds resulted in considerable blowing and drifting snow, and significant disruption to travel.

Cold Arctic air invaded far western Upper Michigan on the morning of the 1st driving wind chills down as cold as 35 below zero.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chills fell as low 35 below zero on the morning of the 1st at the Ironwood AWOS.  Schools were closed on the 1st in Ironwood, Bessemer and Wakefield-Marenisco due to the very cold wind chills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant late season winter storm emerging out of the mid-Mississippi Valley dumped heavy snow over much of western Upper Michigan...especially higher terrain locations along Lake Superior...from the 18th into the 20th.  North winds gusting over 50 mph in the wake of the storm system produced blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy snow and blowing snow from north winds gusting over 50 mph reduced visibility to near zero on the 19th across many locations of northern Houghton County.  The strong north winds also caused extensive drifting of snow.  Storm total snowfall was 21.4 inches at Twin Lakes from late evening on the 18th into the morning of the 20th.  The blizzard conditions forced the early dismissal of area schools on the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A significant late season winter storm emerging out of the mid-Mississippi Valley dumped heavy snow over much of western Upper Michigan...especially higher terrain locations along Lake Superior...from the 18th into the 20th.  North winds gusting over 50 mph in the wake of the storm system produced blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk on the 19th reported heavy snow and extensive blowing and drifting snow from north winds gusting to 50 mph at times.  Mohawk reported a storm total snowfall of 12 inches from the evening of the 18th through the morning of the 20th.  The blizzard conditions forced the early dismissal of area schools on the 19th.

North winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and reduced visibility to one-quarter mile at times on the 19th.  The storm closed most schools throughout the county on the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: From Pelkie to Alston, an estimated six inches of snow fell in 12 hours for the period ending midday on the 19th.  North winds gusting to 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow on the 19th.
