A low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes spread moderate snow across portions of west and south central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported a widespread 3 to 5 inches of snow across Gogebic County, heaviest near Bessemer. Reported snowfall rates were up to an inch an hour at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes spread moderate snow across portions of west and south central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Norway measured 2.7 inches of snow in just over 4 hours. Snowfall rates were reported to be over an inch an hour at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system lifting northeast through the Midwest and Great Lakes brought a period of heavy snow and freezing rain to southern Michigan. Snow totals near 6 inches and ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain and snow overspread the region during the afternoon hours of February 26th, before changing over to all snow in the evening. Ice and snow accumulations on area roadways and reduced visibilities to less than a quarter of a mile at times resulted in hazardous driving conditions. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 4 and 8 inches, with 7 inches of snow accumulation reported 6 miles east-northeast of Jonesville. Ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were also common.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system lifting northeast through the Midwest and Great Lakes brought a period of heavy snow and freezing rain to southern Michigan. Snow totals near 6 inches and ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain and snow overspread the region during the afternoon hours of February 26th, before changing over to all snow in the evening. Ice and snow accumulations on area roadways and reduced visibilities to less than a quarter of a mile at times resulted in hazardous driving conditions. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 4 and 9 inches, with 9 inches of snow accumulation reported in Coldwater. Ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were also common.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers accumulated to between 6 and 10 inches in spots January 31st into the morning hours of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of moderate to heavy lake effect snow developed during the morning hours of January 31st and continued through the late morning hours of February 1st. 24 hour snow accumulations varied across the county, with the heaviest accumulations generally ranging between 5 and 10 inches. There was a report of 9.2 inches near Dowagiac. Temperatures were well below freezing while the snow fell which allowed roads to become snow covered and slick. This resulted in slide-offs and accidents across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure would lift northeastward across northern Lower Michigan in the early morning hours of the 19th.  Out ahead of the system, precipitation fell as snow in eastern Upper Michigan, and as a mix to the south, though this precipitation was relatively light.  As the system departed, strong winds brought in much colder air and accumulating lake effect snow by afternoon on the 19th.  Snow amounts pushed 10 inches at Sault Ste Marie, and ranged from 5 to 8 inches across much of northwest Lower Michigan.  The strong winds resulted in considerable blowing and drifting snow, and significant disruption to travel.

A low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes spread moderate snow across portions of west and south central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported a widespread 3 to 4 inches of snow between Menominee and Bagley. The heaviest snow fell between 6 PM CST and 8 PM CST.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from 2/15-2/16.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Rockland measured 13.0 inches of lake effect snow over a 24 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system lifting northeast through the Midwest and Great Lakes brought a period of heavy snow and freezing rain to southern Michigan. Snow totals near 6 inches and ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain and snow overspread the region during the afternoon hours of February 26th, before changing over to all snow in the evening. Ice and snow accumulations on area roadways and reduced visibilities to less than a quarter of a mile at times resulted in hazardous driving conditions. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 3 and 7 inches, with 6.7 inches of snow accumulation reported in Colon. Ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were also common.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system lifting northeast through the Midwest and Great Lakes brought a period of heavy snow and freezing rain to southern Michigan. Snow totals near 6 inches and ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain and snow overspread the region during the afternoon hours of February 26th, before changing over to all snow in the evening. Ice and snow accumulations on area roadways and reduced visibilities to less than a quarter of a mile at times resulted in hazardous driving conditions. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 2 and 5 inches. Ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were also common.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system lifting northeast through the Midwest and Great Lakes brought a period of heavy snow and freezing rain to southern Michigan. Snow totals near 6 inches and ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mixture of freezing rain and snow overspread the region during the afternoon hours of February 26th, before changing over to all snow in the evening. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 2 and 5 inches. Ice accretions near a tenth of an inch were also common.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a media report of six inches of wet snow in Copper Harbor over approximately an 18-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from Minnesota produced a mix of moderate wet snow, sleet and freezing rain over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters throughout Gogebic County measured between two and four inches of wet snow over an approximate five hour period.  Snow was mixed with sleet at times before changing over to rain or freezing rain later in the evening.  The mixed precipitation caused a two-hour delay at Watersmeet Schools on the 15th and closed the Gogebic County Community College.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from Minnesota produced a mix of moderate wet snow, sleet and freezing rain over portions of the west half of Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many locations throughout the county measured around three inches of wet snow during the afternoon and evening of the 14th before the precipitation changed over to rain or freezing rain early on the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy lake effect snow showers accumulated to between 6 and 10 inches in spots January 31st into the morning hours of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bands of moderate to heavy lake effect snow developed during the morning hours of January 31st and continued through the late morning hours of February 1st. 24 hour snow accumulations varied across the county, with the heaviest accumulations generally ranging between 6 and 10 inches. There were reports of 8.1 inches near Buchanan and 9.8 inches 3 miles west of Niles. Temperatures were well below freezing while the snow fell which allowed roads to become snow covered and slick. This resulted in slide-offs and accidents across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front was advancing north into the southern Great Lakes. Strong overrunning occurred north of the front with surface dew points climbing into the 40s and 50s. This allowed for isolated thunderstorm development. Although instability and moisture was low, plenty of shear allowed the stronger cells to maintain hail cores for an somewhat extended period of time. Isolated severe reports were received.

Low pressure would lift northeastward across northern Lower Michigan in the early morning hours of the 19th.  Out ahead of the system, precipitation fell as snow in eastern Upper Michigan, and as a mix to the south, though this precipitation was relatively light.  As the system departed, strong winds brought in much colder air and accumulating lake effect snow by afternoon on the 19th.  Snow amounts pushed 10 inches at Sault Ste Marie, and ranged from 5 to 8 inches across much of northwest Lower Michigan.  The strong winds resulted in considerable blowing and drifting snow, and significant disruption to travel.
Heavy lake effect snow occurred over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from 2/15-2/16.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Blackjack ski resort estimated 12 inches of snow over 24 hours, with 4 inches of the snow falling in a 6-hour period on the morning of the 16th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow occurred over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from 2/15-2/16.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 12 inches of snow fell in 12 hours on snowmobile trails between Au Train and Wetmore. The report was received via Facebook. Two to three inch per hour snowfall rates were reported by the Department of Highways near Au Train on the morning of 2/16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Ironwood measured 6 inches of snow in 12 hours. Northwest winds gusted to 25 mph causing blowing snow and reduced visibility.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 6 inches of snow fell in 12 hours over much of southern Houghton County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer near Mohawk measured 6.5 inches of snow in 12 hours. Northwest winds gusting to near 30 mph led to blowing snow and reduced visibility.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 10 inches of snow fell near Calumet in 12 hours. Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph led to blowing snow and reduced visibility.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer in Herman measured 8.7 inches of snow over 12 hours, and another observer in L'anse reported 6 inches of snow in 12 hours. Northwest winds up to 30 mph led to blowing snow and reduced visibility.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated storm total snowfall from the evening of the 18th into the afternoon of the 20th reached nearly 30 inches from Wetmore to Shingleton.   North to northwest winds frequently gusting to 40 mph and as high as 50 mph at times caused whiteout conditions while whipping up snow drifts which were 6-8 feet high from the 19th into the 20th.  The blizzard conditions closed Highway M-28 from Harvey to Wetmore from the afternoon of the 19th into the morning of the 21st.  Department of Transportation crews were still clearing 6-8 feet drifts and stranded vehicles from Highway M-28 into the afternoon of the 20th.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 19th and 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the region brought brief moderate snow to portions of central Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter five miles west of Iron River measured 2.5 inches of snow over a two-hour period.  Roads were reported to be snow-covered and slippery.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the region brought brief moderate snow to portions of central Upper Michigan on the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Watson measured three inches of wet snow in three hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured 14 inches of storm total snowfall from the evening of the 18th into the morning of the 20th.  Estimated snowfall rates of two inches per hour and near zero visibility were reported during the height of the blizzard conditions. Frequent north to northwest wind gusts near 40 mph whipped up snow drifts as high as four feet causing roads to be impassible. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 19th and 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Bark River measured 5.2 inches of snow in 12 hours.  Far northern reaches of Delta County measured closer to a foot of storm total snowfall during the event.  Northwest winds gusting near 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting snow and lowered visibility on the 19th and 20th.  Many schools were closed on the 19th while some schools were either closed or delayed on the 20th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Ironwood estimated two to three inches of snow in less than eight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Bark River measured 6.7 inches of snow in less than 12 hours. Some blowing and drifting of snow was also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Norway measured 3.3 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured 3.9 inches of snow in 13 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Newberry measured three inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper dropped between 2 and 4 inches of accumulating snow on the region, with heavier amounts in excess of 6 inches near the Lake Michigan shoreline in southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow covered roads led to a few accidents and slide-offs across the region on February 2nd as light to moderate snow fell for much of the day. Total snow accumulations ranged between 3 and 6 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 4.3 inches of snow in Jacobsville in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Parent Bay measured three inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of five inches of snow in six hours just south of Harvey.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over much of the east half of Upper Michigan on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Gladstone measured 3.5 inches of wet snow in approximately 15 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over much of the east half of Upper Michigan on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Menominee measured three inches of wet snow on the morning of the 27th.  Roads were reported to be very slippery.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over much of the east half of Upper Michigan on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 2.5 inches of wet snow fell in six hours in Manistique.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over much of the east half of Upper Michigan on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service employee near Harvey measured six inches of wet snow in eight hours.  During the same time period, four inches of snow fell at the National Weather Service office.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over much of the east half of Upper Michigan on the 27th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer south of Wetmore measured nearly three inches of wet snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper approached the region from the northwest on the 3rd.  Preexisting lake effect snow was pushed into far northern Lower Michigan, resulting in a burst of very heavy snow on the 3rd.  Cross Village picked up just over 10 inches of snow in less than four hours.

A clipper approached the region from the northwest on the 3rd.  Preexisting lake effect snow was pushed into far northern Lower Michigan, resulting in a burst of very heavy snow on the 3rd.  Cross Village picked up just over 10 inches of snow in less than four hours.

Arctic high pressure would move off to the east late on the 6th.  Light snow developed late at night on the 6th, as warmer air tried to work north into the region.  Much heavier snow got going on the afternoon and evening of the 7th, as low pressure crossed northwest Ohio and southeast Lower Michigan.  By morning on the 8th, snowfall amounts topped out at around 10 inches in the Gladwin, Tawas, and Standish areas.
A low pressure system moving from the Plains into Ontario dumped heavy snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 22nd into the morning of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Pelkie measured six inches of wet snow over an approximate 12-hour period.  The observer in Baraga measured nearly four inches of wet snow and also observed a period of freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving from the Plains into Ontario dumped heavy snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 22nd into the morning of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Ironwood to Wakefield measured anywhere from seven to nine inches of wet snow from the evening of the 22nd through the morning of the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving from the Plains into Ontario dumped heavy snow over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 22nd into the morning of the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated six inches of wet snow fell along and just south of Highway M-38 over a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper dropped between 2 and 4 inches of accumulating snow on the region, with heavier amounts in excess of 6 inches near the Lake Michigan shoreline in southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow covered roads led to a few accidents and slide-offs across the region on February 2nd as light to moderate snow fell for much of the day. Total snow accumulations ranged between 2 and 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper dropped between 2 and 4 inches of accumulating snow on the region, with heavier amounts in excess of 6 inches near the Lake Michigan shoreline in southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow covered roads led to a few accidents and slide-offs across the region on February 2nd as light to moderate snow fell for much of the day. Total snow accumulations ranged between 2 and 4 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense lake effect snow band dropped a quick 4 to 12 inches of heavy snow across far southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy lake effect snow pivoted through Berrien County late January 23rd into the early morning hours of January 24th. Snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour were common within this band. Snowfall totals ranged from around 4 inches in eastern portions of the county to between 8 and 12 inches in the west. There was a report of a foot of snow accumulation near Stevensville. Roads became snow covered and slick which led to slide-offs and accidents across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather struck portions of Southwest Lower Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of May 20th.  Damaging winds and large hail accompanied the strongest storms.  As the temperature and humidity levels climbed through the day, this led to a very unstable airmass in Michigan.  The arrival of a wave of low pressure triggered the storms shortly after noon.  As this feature tracked northeastward through Lower Michigan through the afternoon and evening, the storms strengthened and expanded in coverage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A one and a quarter inch diameter hail report was received from Newaygo county at Hardy Dam from an amateur radio operator.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather struck portions of Southwest Lower Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of May 20th.  Damaging winds and large hail accompanied the strongest storms.  As the temperature and humidity levels climbed through the day, this led to a very unstable airmass in Michigan.  The arrival of a wave of low pressure triggered the storms shortly after noon.  As this feature tracked northeastward through Lower Michigan through the afternoon and evening, the storms strengthened and expanded in coverage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported one inch diameter hail.

As the temperature and humidity levels climbed through the day, this led to a very unstable airmass in Michigan.  The arrival of a wave of low pressure triggered the storms shortly after noon.  As this feature tracked northeastward through Lower Michigan through the afternoon and evening, the storms strengthened and expanded in coverage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A three quarters inch hail report was received from Kalamazoo county near Long Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very cold air was in place over the region, in advance of a clipper moving southeast from central Canada. The clipper was moisture-starved, and would only produce very light snow away from the Great Lakes.  However, southwest winds ahead of the clipper interacted with pre-existing lake effect snow to produce very heavy snow in western Mackinac County.  Engadine picked up 8 inches of snow, while media reports indicated Curtis ended up with nearly two feet of fresh snow.

A strong cold front turned mixed rain and snow over to lake effect snow showers on the night of the 30th.  Those snow showers intensified during the day on the 31st, thanks to a passing upper level disturbance.  Snow totals ranged from 4 to 12 inches in western Chippewa County, with the highest totals near Paradise.  Further south, 5 to 8 inches of snow fell south and east of Grand Traverse Bay.

An intense Lake Huron snow band produced locally up to 11 inches over Croswell in far southeastern Sanilac county. The snow came down in a short 6 hour window.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large limbs were blown down in Alma by gusts estimated up to 60 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few reports of damaging wind gusts and large hail were received on May 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three quarters inch hail was reported near Lake George.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were public reports of six to seven inches of wet snow at McMillan and Newberry over a 12-hour period.  Northeast winds gusting over 25 mph also caused drifting of snow.  Tahquamenon Area Schools were closed on the 12th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread 12-hour snowfall amounts between six and eight inches were reported across southern Schoolcraft County. The wet snow closed schools throughout the county on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated six to seven inches of wet snow fell across much of northern Schoolcraft County in approximately a 12-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Sidnaw measured 3.5 inches of wet snow in less than ten hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Watton measured four inches of wet snow in approximately eight hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Iron River measured five inches of wet snow in less than 12 hours.  The snow closed schools throughout the county on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms impacted the Detroit Metro Area with isolated wind gusts up to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 9 inch diameter tree limb was reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough deepening over the Great Lakes generated thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th. Some of the storms turned severe over Gogebic and Dickinson counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Cooks measured over five inches of rainfall over an approximate 24-hour period.  Over five inches of rain also fell in Manistique.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A weak upper level system moved through the central Great Lakes during the evening hours of the 21st. Widely scattered thunderstorms developed ahead of the system, with an isolated report of wind damage as one of the larger storms collapsed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pictures were posted on a local media outlets social media page of large tree branches being blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary south of M-59 triggered two severe thunderstorms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 12 inch diameter tree was reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through and warm and unstable air mass produced a severe thunderstorm in Melstrand on the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the Melstrand area, about 30 trees were down or snapped off and 6 to 8 trees uprooted in Melstrand. One 30-inch diameter white pine was snapped off one-third of the way up.  At a cabin, sheet metal fencing which was nailed down to protect a well head was blown off and became airborne, gouging a storage shed 100 feet away with gouges 6.5 feet off the ground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado formed 4 miles south-southeast of Bancroft and tracked east-northeastward for about 5.5 miles before exiting Shiawaseee County about 3 miles north-northeast of Byron at 2019EST. The tornado continued in Genesee County for another 4 miles, before dissipating at 2024EST. The tornado was rated EF1 with maximum winds to 100 mph. Path width was 550 yards. The tornado started just south of the intersection of Britton and Grand River Roads. The tornado moved northeast near the city of Byron, before exiting Shiawassee County. Many trees were uprooted and snapped. 50 percent of a roof and siding were torn off a home. An old barn was destroyed and another whole roof was torn off.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was rated EF2 with maximum wind speeds of 115 mph. The maximum path width was 500 yards with a total path length of 5.1 miles. The tornado started along Odell Road south of Linden Road and continued to Fenton Road north of Baldwin Road. The greatest damage occurred along Thompson Road between Fairbanks and Jennings Roads. There was significant damage to homes, including removal of roofs, along with substantial tree damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air-mass advected into the region.  Outflow from morning convection and some mid/high clouds helped to keep the area capped for most of the day.  Convection began firing over Iowa around 18 UTC and quickly formed into a forward propagating Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) that followed the instability gradient into far southern Lower Michigan during the evening hours. The storms were most intense as they moved off the lake, but slowly weakened with time. Despite the weakening trend, damaging winds were reported well into the evening..
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported an eight inch tree limb down across the road at North Angling and Butler in Centreville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough deepening over the Great Lakes generated thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th. Some of the storms turned severe over Gogebic and Dickinson counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximate 24-hour rainfall measured 4.31 inches at Garden Corners.  Over four inches of rainfall was also measured at Bark River during the same time period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong thunderstorm moving through Gogebic County produced tree damage from Black River Harbor to Ironwood and Wakefield on the afternoon on the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter reported a few poplar trees and several small branches knocked down from Black River Harbor to Ironwood and Wakefield.  Time of the event was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very warm and unstable air-mass advected into the region.  Outflow from morning convection and some mid/high clouds helped to keep the area capped for most of the day.  Convection began firing over Iowa around 18 UTC and quickly formed into a forward propagating Mesoscale Convective System (MCS) that followed the instability gradient into far southern Lower Michigan during the evening hours. The storms were most intense as they moved off the lake, but slowly weakened with time. Despite the weakening trend, damaging winds were reported well into the evening..
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local law enforcement officials reported numerous trees and power lines down across mainly the southern half of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tornado was rated EF0 with maximum winds to 75 mph. Path width was 60 yards and path length 3/4 mile. The tornado started at Lansing and Warner roads, and followed lansing road and then crossed I-69. The tornado ended at the entrance ramp of the highway rest area. Many trees were uprooted and shingles were torn off a church.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was rated EF0 with maximum winds to 75 mph. Path width was 100 yards and path length 1/2 mile. The tornado started at Bethemy Cemetary and moved northeast, ending at West Britton and Hidden Ridge Roads. Trees were uprooted and many tree limbs were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A few severe thunderstorms impacted the Detroit Metro Area with isolated wind gusts up to 60 mph.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 14 inch diameter tree limb was reported blown down, taking the power lines down as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was rated an EF1 with maximum wind speeds of 105 mph. The maximum path width was 400 yards with a total path length of 2.3 miles. The tornado started at the southern end of Hasselbring Park and continued northeast to around the intersection of Harry Street and Humprey Avenue. The greatest damage occurred along Saginaw Street in between Holtslander and Downey Avenues. There was significant tree damage as well as damage to older commercial buildings of small to medium size.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large tree limbs up to 12 inch in diameter were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This tornado formed 4 miles south-southeast of Bancroft in Shiawassee County and entered Genesee County about 1.5 miles west-southwest of Gaines at 2019EST. The tornado then continued for another 4.3 miles before dissipating 1.3 miles northwest of|the Gaines Airport at 2024EST. While in Genesee County, the tornado was rated EF0 with maximum winds to 80 mph.  The path width was 200 yards.  The tornado ended at the intersection of Baldwin and Seymour roads.  Many trees were uprooted and snapped. One barn lost a section of roof.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level area of low pressure and associated jet streak allowed for favorable conditions for thunderstorm development across much of the southern Great Lakes. Isolated wind damage was reported in Berrien county as a storm came onshore from Lake Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a three to four block radius of Chikaming Township suffering widespread tree as well as structural damage. Tree damage ranged from large broken tree limbs to uprooted trees. Some of these trees impacted structures, causing roof damage. The location of the damage was immediately adjacent to the shores of Lake Michigan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm impacted Southwest Oakland County.
An isolated severe thunderstorm impacted Southwest Oakland County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Canadian high pressure moving over the region resulted in widespread frost over interior portions of Upper Michigan during the early morning hours of the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Low temperatures on the morning of the 3rd ranged from 24 degrees at Doe Lake to 32 degrees in Munising resulting in widespread frost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Canadian high pressure moving over the region resulted in widespread frost over interior portions of Upper Michigan during the early morning hours of the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observed minimum temperatures in the upper 20s and lower 30s on the morning of the 3rd resulted in widespread frost.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Canadian high pressure moving over the region resulted in widespread frost over interior portions of Upper Michigan during the early morning hours of the 3rd and 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Garden Corners and near Rapid River reported respective minimum temperatures of 31 and 32 degrees on the morning of the 3rd.  Areas of frost were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Steep low level lapse rates and dry low levels ahead of a cold front, allowed for the development some a few thunderstorms across central Lower Michigan, which dropped southeast. A few of these storms clipped portions of Branch and St Joseph counties with isolated damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Amateur radio operators reported a four inch diameter tree and some small tree limbs down near Sherwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Influenced by a highly unstable, but strongly capped atmosphere ahead of a frontal boundary moving out of Illinois, the combination of 3000 to 4000 j/kg surface based CAPE, mid-level lapse rates between 8 and 9 C/km and 0-6 km deep layer shear of 35 to 55 knots set the stage for rapid supercellular development. The convection transitioned to clusters of bowing segments as storms congealed producing an increased risk for high end damaging wind. Broad, but strong rotation established quickly in the initial storms, allowing for rapid production of hail, some exceeding gold ball size. Numerous funnel clouds were reported in the early stages of the event, indicating conditions were favorable for tornadic development. However, the development of tornadoes was severely limited due to just enough mixed layer inhibition in the lowest levels.
Scattered severe thunderstorms developed, with Oakland and Washtenaw Counties being hardest hit, where flash flooding also occured.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain from thunderstorms caused flooding up to 4 feet deep, with several high water rescues needed from emergency personnel as cars stalled in the high water.|Spotter reports indicate 2 to 4 inches of rain fell within a 2 to 3 hour window.

The damage path associated with this storm was about one half mile long and roughly 200 yards wide.  The winds were estimated to be around 80 mph, causing over 100 trees to be snapped or uprooted.  Some of these trees actually landed on camps as well as other structures causing significant damage.

The estimated 65 mph peak winds uprooted trees and broke off large limbs. One tree fell on a mobile home while the owner was sitting nearby and caused a fire to break out in the kitchen when it landed on a stove.  Fallen trees caused damage to other houses and totaled at least one vehicle.  In addition a portion of the roof of the county road commission garage was tore off.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers measured a widespread 3 to 5 inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak disturbances moving across Lake Superior brought moderate lake effect snow to portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 2nd into the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Shingleton measured nearly seven inches of lake effect snow in approximately 12 hours.  Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused blowing snow and reduced visibility during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak disturbances moving across Lake Superior brought moderate lake effect snow to portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 2nd into the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Grand Marais measured six inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Significant ice jam flooding occurred on the Muskegon River in Mecosta County.  Evacuations occurred along the Muskegon River near Rogers Heights.  Over a dozen homes were evacuated and flooded.  Riverside Drive and 183rd Avenue (12th Mile Road) in particular was an area that experienced significant flooding.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A significant ice jam on the Muskegon River resulted in evacuations of over a dozen homes along the Muskegon River near Rogers Heights, all of which were flooded.  Riverside Drive and 183rd Avenue (12th Mile Road) in particular were local areas of particularly significant flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region bringing a widespread heavy wet snow to western and north central Upper Michigan on 2/10. Freezing rain was also reported during the event. Lake effect snow then impacted western Upper Michigan during the day on 2/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 0.1 inch of freezing rain was observed at the Marquette National Weather Service office. Additionally, several car accidents near Marquette were reported as a result of the freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Bark River estimated 8 to 9 inches of snow in less than 12 hours with over one-inch per hour snowfall rates observed.  Widespread 8 to 11 inch storm total snowfall amounts were reported throughout the county along with near whiteout conditions in blowing snow.  Area schools were closed on the 31st due to effects from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Chatham, Munising, and 10 miles south of Grand Marais reported around 8 inches of snow over a 12 hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region bringing a widespread heavy wet snow to western and north central Upper Michigan on 2/10. Freezing rain was also reported during the event. Lake effect snow then impacted western Upper Michigan during the day on 2/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy snow was observed by several spotters across Keweenaw County. Observers near Mohawk and Lac La Belle measured 3.0 inches of snow in approximately 3 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Menominee County emergency manager reported 12-hour snowfall totals of 5 to 7 inches in Menominee and 6 to 8 inches from Daggett to Carney.  North winds gusting to 25 mph caused poor visibility in blowing snow and also caused considerable drifting of snow with 3 to 4 foot drifts being reported near Daggett and Carney.  Poor road conditions and visibility reduced to less than one-half mile were reported on US-41 between Menominee and Carney.  Menominee Schools were closed on the 30th and were on a two-hour delay on the 31st due to effects from the storm.  Carney-Nadeau and Stephenson schools were closed on the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread snowfall totals of 7 to 9 inches and poor road conditions were reported throughout southern Schoolcraft County.  Manistique Area Schools were closed on the 31st due to effects from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of eight inches of snow in less than 12 hours at McMillan while Newberry measured between seven and eight inches in less than 12 hours.  Tahquamenon Area Schools were closed on the 31st due to effects from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region bringing a widespread heavy wet snow to western and north central Upper Michigan on 2/10. Freezing rain was also reported during the event. Lake effect snow then impacted western Upper Michigan during the day on 2/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy snow was observed in Paulding and 8 miles west southwest of Ontonagon. The observer west southwest of Ontonagon reported 3 inches of snow in 3 hours between 7 PM EST and 9 PM EST. The observer in Paulding measured 4 inches of snow over 14 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region bringing a widespread heavy wet snow to western and north central Upper Michigan on 2/10. Freezing rain was also reported during the event. Lake effect snow then impacted western Upper Michigan during the day on 2/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observer near Chassell measured 3.4 inches of snow in just over 12 hours. The observer also reported a 0.1 inch of mixed sleet and freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region bringing a widespread heavy wet snow to western and north central Upper Michigan on 2/10. Freezing rain was also reported during the event. Lake effect snow then impacted western Upper Michigan during the day on 2/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Bessemer estimated 4 to 6 inches of moderate lake effect snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moved from the Central Plains into the Great Lakes region bringing a widespread heavy wet snow to western and north central Upper Michigan on 2/10. Freezing rain was also reported during the event. Lake effect snow then impacted western Upper Michigan during the day on 2/11.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observer at Mohawk measured 4.1 inches of lake effect snow over 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers south of Grand Marais and near Munising measured 14 inches of snow over 24 hours.  There was also a report of an estimated 12 inches of snow in just over 12 hours north of Shingleton on the 30th.  Near whiteout conditions in blowing snow and poor road conditions were reported throughout the county.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 31st due to effects from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of eight inches of snow in Seney in less than nine hours.  Poor road conditions and poor visibility in blowing snow were common.  The Michigan State Police reported that slippery roads contributed to a fatal accident that occurred just west of the Seney rest area around 4 pm EST on the 30th.  A 39-year-old Marquette man was killed when the passenger car he was driving lost control and slid into a logging truck on Highway M-28.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Bessemer measured 7.5 inches of snow in 24 hours.  The Gogebic County Sheriff's Department reported that poor visibility in heavy snow contributed to an accident involving a car and a snowmobile on the afternoon of the 30th.  A 57-year-old man attempting to cross Highway US-2 on his snowmobile was struck by a car. The man was taken to Aspirus Grandview Hospital for a severe leg injury.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured a storm total of 17 inches into the morning of the 31st.  Gusty north winds to 30 mph contributed to poor visibility and poor road conditions due to considerable blowing and drifting snow.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 31st due to the effects of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in the Norway-Iron Mountain area measured four to five inches of snow in ten hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Herman measured 12 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak disturbances moving across Lake Superior brought moderate lake effect snow to portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 2nd into the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Freda and Calumet measured three to four inches of lake effect snow in approximately 12 hours.  The spotter in Freda reported northwest winds gusting over 30 mph with blowing snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak disturbances moving across Lake Superior brought moderate lake effect snow to portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 2nd into the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured 4.5 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours while a spotter in Eagle Harbor estimated five to six inches of snow in approximately ten hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening low pressure system tracking east through the Ohio Valley region dropped between 6 and 12 inches of heavy snow on southwest Lower Michigan, mainly during the afternoon and evening hours of March 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread the area during the afternoon hours of March 5th and became heavy at times during the evening and early overnight hours. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 9 and 12 inches. There was a report of 10.8 inches in Saint Joseph. The intensity of the heavy snow and sub-freezing surface temperatures allowed the snow to accumulate on roadways. This resulted in hazardous travel conditions across the region with numerous school closings the morning of March 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of November 17th in advance of a strong cold front.  The storms blew down and uprooted numerous trees across lower Michigan, caused numerous power outages, significant straight line wind damage and even several brief weak EF-0 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced multiple brief EF-0 tornadoes along a more than 50 mile path from Muskegon county northeast through Newaygo county into Mecosta county.  The tornadoes were on the ground for very short periods of time.  Mostly tree damage was incurred but there was also damage to several buildings and fences.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of November 17th in advance of a strong cold front.  The storms blew down and uprooted numerous trees across lower Michigan, caused numerous power outages, significant straight line wind damage and even several brief weak EF-0 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced multiple brief EF-0 tornadoes along a more than 50 mile path from Muskegon county northeast through Newaygo county into Mecosta county.  The tornadoes were on the ground for very short periods of time.  Mostly tree damage was incurred but there was also damage to several buildings and fences.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm moist air lifting over the area ahead of an approaching cold front produced widespread light freezing rain over much of Upper Michigan on the morning of the 29th. Many schools were closed or delayed as a result of the freezing rain.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread light freezing rain caused many schools to close throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter near Pine Stump Junction estimated 12 inches of snow over 12 hours. Northwest winds up to 30 mph led to blowing snow and reduced visibility.  Tahquamenon Area Schools were closed on the 19th and 20th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Houghton County Road Commission estimated storm total snowfall amount between 12 and 15 inches in Calumet from the evening of the 18th into the morning of the 20th. Estimated snowfall rates of two inches per hour and near zero visibility were reported at both Houghton and Calumet during the height of the blizzard conditions.  Frequent north to northwest wind gusts near 40 mph whipped up snow drifts as high as four feet causing roads to be impassible.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 19th and 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 6 inches of snow fell in 12 hours across portions of southern Schoolcraft County. Northwest winds up to 30 mph led to blowing snow and reduced visibility from the 19th into the morning of the 20th.  Manistique Area Schools were closed on the 19th and 20th due to the effects of storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 8 inches of snow was observed across northern Schoolcraft County in 12 hours. Northwest winds up to 30 mph led to blowing snow and reduced visibility from the 19th into the afternoon of the 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter 10 miles east of Ontonagon measured 8 inches of snow in 12 hours. Ontonagon Schools were closed on the 19th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A major winter storm impacted portions of west and north central Upper Michigan 2/18-2/20. Blizzard conditions developed across the Keweenaw Peninsula and Alger County from 2/19-2/20.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A storm total of 14.5 inches of snow fell at the National Weather Service office three miles northeast of Negaunee. Northwest winds gusting up to 40 mph at times led to occasional white out conditions due to blowing snow. Snowfall rates over an inch an hour were reported during the height of the storm. Schools were closed on 2/19 and 2/20 due to the effects of the storm.  ||Slippery conditions from the storm contributed to a three-vehicle crash on the morning of the 19th along Highway M-553 just north of Stonegate Drive in Sands Township.  Injured drivers of two of the vehicles were transported via ambulance to Marquette General Hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer south of Wetmore measured 6.3 inches of snow in less than 12 hours.  A spotter in Munising measured five inches of snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking through the Lower Great Lakes dropped moderate snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 22nd into the 23rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Menominee measured three inches of snow in approximately eight hours.  Visibility reduced to one-quarter mile in snow and blowing snow along with slippery road conditions were also reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Record flooding occurred during the month of April and record crests occurred on the lower portions of the Grand River at Ionia, Lowell, Ada, Comstock Park, and Grand Rapids, Michigan. Due to the severity of the flooding, Michigan���s Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster for 19 counties and two cities.  ||The two cities declared in the disaster were Grand Rapids and Ionia.  The counties included in the disaster declaration included Barry, Gratiot, Ionia, Kent, Mecosta, Muskegon, Newaygo, Osceola and Ottawa.  Hundreds of homes were flooded, over 300 roads closed, and preliminary flood damage estimates were in excess of 32 million dollars.  ||On a positive note, no lives were lost during this record flooding.||Parts of West Michigan experienced flooding rainfall from the afternoon of April 17th through the day on April 18th. Most areas saw between 2 to 4 inches of rainfall. Some local areas near Holland and Grand Rapids saw around 5 inches of rainfall. All of this rainfall fell on top of already fully saturated soil from big rains that came during early to mid April. ||The flooding in many areas lingered through the weekend of April 20th and 21st into the following week.  In downtown Grand Rapids flooding problems did not reach their peak until April 22nd, when the Grand River in Grand Rapids crested at 21.85 feet, causing significant flooding damage to numerous businesses and homes near the river.||Record stages were set at 5 River Forecast Points:||The Grand River at Ionia, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 24.69 feet; the old record was 24.30 feet set back in 1948.  This also set a flow/discharge record at 25,100 cubic feet per second (cfs).||The Grand River at Lowell, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 19.02 feet; the old record was 19.00 feet set back in 1948.  ||The Grand River at Ada, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 22.94 feet; the old |record was 21.60 feet set back in 1986.  ||The Grand River at Grand Rapids, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 21.85 feet; the old record was 19.64 feet set back in 1985.  However, this was only the fifth highest flow/discharge at 35,100 cfs.||The Grand River at Comstock Park, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 17.80 feet; the old record was 17.75 feet set back in 1948.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused significant flooding on rivers and streams across Kent county. Kent County authorities estimated that flooding caused an estimated $10.6 million in damage, not including the City of Grand Rapids.  Including the city of Grand Rapids flood damage estimated reach 20 million with significant flooding occurring to numerous homes and businesses. ||Kent County Emergency Management supervisors released the latest numbers Thursday, May 16, based on a damage assessment team evaluation. Flood waters in Kent County began to cause damage on April 18 when local creeks, including Buck Creek, began to overflow in parts of Wyoming, Grandville and elsewhere.||In downtown Grand Rapids, the problem reached its worst point when the Grand River crested at 21.85 feet on April 22.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening low pressure system tracked across the southern Great Lakes Thursday and Friday (February 7-8) bringing widespread snowfall to Southeast Michigan. Snow started earlier across the Saginaw Valley and the Thumb, bringing the highest snowfall totals of 7 to 10 inches to that region, with generally 3 to 6 inches further south.  Lesser amounts were found south of the Metro Detroit area, as dry air had to be overcome and warm air filtered in ahead of the system.  This lead to a period of freezing rain and sleet, with some locations reporting up to 0.10 inches of ice.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Midland (Midland) 12.0 inches.|Bay Port (Huron) 10.7 inches.|Auburn (Bay) 8.2 inches.|Merrill (Saginaw) 8.0 inches.|Peck (Sanilac) 6.5 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 6.5 inches.

A strengthening low pressure system tracked across the southern Great Lakes Thursday and Friday (February 7-8) bringing widespread snowfall to Southeast Michigan. Snow started earlier across the Saginaw Valley and the Thumb, bringing the highest snowfall totals of 7 to 10 inches to that region, with generally 3 to 6 inches further south.  Lesser amounts were found south of the Metro Detroit area, as dry air had to be overcome and warm air filtered in ahead of the system.  This lead to a period of freezing rain and sleet, with some locations reporting up to 0.10 inches of ice.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Midland (Midland) 12.0 inches.|Bay Port (Huron) 10.7 inches.|Auburn (Bay) 8.2 inches.|Merrill (Saginaw) 8.0 inches.|Peck (Sanilac) 6.5 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 6.5 inches.

Record flooding occurred during the month of April and record crests occurred on the lower portions of the Grand River at Ionia, Lowell, Ada, Comstock Park, and Grand Rapids, Michigan. Due to the severity of the flooding, Michigan���s Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster for 19 counties and two cities.  ||The two cities declared in the disaster were Grand Rapids and Ionia.  The counties included in the disaster declaration included Barry, Gratiot, Ionia, Kent, Mecosta, Muskegon, Newaygo, Osceola and Ottawa.  Hundreds of homes were flooded, over 300 roads closed, and preliminary flood damage estimates were in excess of 32 million dollars.  ||On a positive note, no lives were lost during this record flooding.||Parts of West Michigan experienced flooding rainfall from the afternoon of April 17th through the day on April 18th. Most areas saw between 2 to 4 inches of rainfall. Some local areas near Holland and Grand Rapids saw around 5 inches of rainfall. All of this rainfall fell on top of already fully saturated soil from big rains that came during early to mid April. ||The flooding in many areas lingered through the weekend of April 20th and 21st into the following week.  In downtown Grand Rapids flooding problems did not reach their peak until April 22nd, when the Grand River in Grand Rapids crested at 21.85 feet, causing significant flooding damage to numerous businesses and homes near the river.||Record stages were set at 5 River Forecast Points:||The Grand River at Ionia, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 24.69 feet; the old record was 24.30 feet set back in 1948.  This also set a flow/discharge record at 25,100 cubic feet per second (cfs).||The Grand River at Lowell, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 19.02 feet; the old record was 19.00 feet set back in 1948.  ||The Grand River at Ada, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 22.94 feet; the old |record was 21.60 feet set back in 1986.  ||The Grand River at Grand Rapids, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 21.85 feet; the old record was 19.64 feet set back in 1985.  However, this was only the fifth highest flow/discharge at 35,100 cfs.||The Grand River at Comstock Park, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 17.80 feet; the old record was 17.75 feet set back in 1948.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall caused significant flooding on rivers and streams across Eaton county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving, occluded low pressure system was nearly parked across the far northern Great Lakes.  A light synoptic snowfall gave way to more substantial lake effect snow during the day on the 19th.  By evening, snowfall totals were around a foot in areas just west of Traverse City (including Lake Ann, Leland, Interlochen, and Brethren).  Meanwhile, 6 to 8 inches of snow fell in the lake effect snow belts from Petoskey, to East Jordan, to near Gaylord.

A strong cold front moving through the area generated heavy lake effect snow showers over Marquette County and moderate lake effect snow over Gogebic County from the evening of the 15th into the morning of the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of four to five inches of lake effect snow in Wakefield over a 12-hour period.  An estimated six inches of lake effect snow fell in 12 hours at Bessemer.

Due to the severity of the flooding, Michigan���s Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster for 19 counties and two cities.  ||The two cities declared in the disaster were Grand Rapids and Ionia.  The counties included in the disaster declaration included Barry, Gratiot, Ionia, Kent, Mecosta, Muskegon, Newaygo, Osceola and Ottawa.  Hundreds of homes were flooded, over 300 roads closed, and preliminary flood damage estimates were in excess of 32 million dollars.  ||On a positive note, no lives were lost during this record flooding.||Parts of West Michigan experienced flooding rainfall from the afternoon of April 17th through the day on April 18th. Most areas saw between 2 to 4 inches of rainfall. Some local areas near Holland and Grand Rapids saw around 5 inches of rainfall. All of this rainfall fell on top of already fully saturated soil from big rains that came during early to mid April. ||The flooding in many areas lingered through the weekend of April 20th and 21st into the following week.  In downtown Grand Rapids flooding problems did not reach their peak until April 22nd, when the Grand River in Grand Rapids crested at 21.85 feet, causing significant flooding damage to numerous businesses and homes near the river.||Record stages were set at 5 River Forecast Points:||The Grand River at Ionia, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 24.69 feet; the old record was 24.30 feet set back in 1948.  This also set a flow/discharge record at 25,100 cubic feet per second (cfs).||The Grand River at Lowell, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 19.02 feet; the old record was 19.00 feet set back in 1948.  ||The Grand River at Ada, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 22.94 feet; the old |record was 21.60 feet set back in 1986.  ||The Grand River at Grand Rapids, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 21.85 feet; the old record was 19.64 feet set back in 1985.  However, this was only the fifth highest flow/discharge at 35,100 cfs.||The Grand River at Comstock Park, Michigan, set a new crest stage record of 17.80 feet; the old record was 17.75 feet set back in 1948.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain caused significant flooding on rivers and streams across Osceola county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening low pressure system tracked across the southern Great Lakes Thursday and Friday (February 7-8) bringing widespread snowfall to Southeast Michigan. Snow started earlier across the Saginaw Valley and the Thumb, bringing the highest snowfall totals of 7 to 10 inches to that region, with generally 3 to 6 inches further south.  Lesser amounts were found south of the Metro Detroit area, as dry air had to be overcome and warm air filtered in ahead of the system.  This lead to a period of freezing rain and sleet, with some locations reporting up to 0.10 inches of ice.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Midland (Midland) 12.0 inches.|Bay Port (Huron) 10.7 inches.|Auburn (Bay) 8.2 inches.|Merrill (Saginaw) 8.0 inches.|Peck (Sanilac) 6.5 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 6.5 inches.

This lead to a period of freezing rain and sleet, with some locations reporting up to 0.10 inches of ice.  |Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Midland (Midland) 12.0 inches.|Bay Port (Huron) 10.7 inches.|Auburn (Bay) 8.2 inches.|Merrill (Saginaw) 8.0 inches.|Peck (Sanilac) 6.5 inches.|Port Huron (St. Clair) 6.5 inches.

Colder air flowing across Lake Superior combined with the passage of an upper level disturbance to produce moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured 6.3 inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air flowing across Lake Superior combined with the passage of an upper level disturbance to produce moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service Office in Negaunee Township measured 6.5 inches in during the evening of the 12th.  The observer near Ishpeming measured 5.4 inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air flowing across Lake Superior combined with the passage of an upper level disturbance to produce moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles south of Grand Marais measured 7.5 inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through the area generated heavy lake effect snow showers over Marquette County and moderate lake effect snow over Gogebic County from the evening of the 15th into the morning of the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service employee five miles south of Marquette measured between nine and ten inches of lake effect snow in 12 hours.  Seven inches of snow fell in Negaunee during the same period.

Colder air flowing across Lake Superior combined with the passage of an upper level disturbance to produce moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Bessemer estimated ten inches of snow in an approximately 15-18 hour period.  Snow fell heavy at times with over one-inch per hour snowfall rates.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air flowing across Lake Superior combined with the passage of an upper level disturbance to produce moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Rockland measured 8.4 inches of snow in approximately ten hours.  It was still snowing heavily into the late afternoon hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Colder air flowing across Lake Superior combined with the passage of an upper level disturbance to produce moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 12th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Calumet estimated five to eight inches of lake effect snow in nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Daggett measured six inches of wet snow in 12 hours while five inches of snow fell in Stephenson and Powers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system originating near Texas tracked northeast into the Ohio Valley. As the low lifted north, a mix of rain, freezing rain, sleet, and snow commenced Tuesday afternoon. A changeover to snow began between 4-7 PM for most areas. A general 3 to 5 inch swath of snow fell across most of Southeast Michigan, with up to 7 inches falling in Ann Arbor and Dexter in Washnetaw county. The heavy wet snow and wind lead to power outages in and around Ann Arbor.

A significant late season winter storm emerging out of the mid-Mississippi Valley dumped heavy snow over much of western Upper Michigan...especially higher terrain locations along Lake Superior...from the 18th into the 20th.  North winds gusting over 50 mph in the wake of the storm system produced blizzard conditions over the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter five miles west of Bruce Crossing estimated 13 to 15 inches of storm total snowfall. Strong north winds gusting over 30 mph at times caused extensive blowing and drifting of snow.  Whiteout conditions were observed at times and drifts were reportedly two feet high.  The spotter in Paulding measured a foot of storm total snowfall.  The storm closed schools throughout the county on the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A frontal boundary stalled over Michigan dropping 3 to 6 inches of rain. This resulted in the flooding of some rivers, streams and low-lying areas. Dozens of roads were closed across the following counties: Midland, Bay, Saginaw, Tuscola, Lapeer, and St. Clair. Several roads were also reported to be damaged. Hundreds of basements were flooded, with some property damage also reported.||Here are some of the higher 5 day rainfall totals between April 7th and 12th. |NWS cooperative weather station reports:|Lapeer 2w  (Lapeer county): 5.04 inches|Midland  (Midland county): 4.96 inches|Lexington (Sanilac county):  4.91 inches|Owosso (Shiawassee county): 4.74 inches|Auburn 2ne (Bay county): 4.58 inches|Merrill, 2e (Saginaw county): 4.57 inches|Port Huron  (St. Clair county): 4.07 inches|Vassar (Tuscola county): 3.90 inches|Port Austin wwtp (Huron county): 3.61 inches|Mt. Clemens (Macomb county): 3.39 inches|Goodrich (Genessee county):  3.03 inches.

A warm front lifted through Southeast Michigan, with strong winds within the warm sector leading to gusts up to 60 mph over Washtenaw and Wayne counties, causing a few downed trees and powerlines. A surface trough then initiated scattered severe thunderstorms which produced wind damage.

A warm front lifted through Southeast Michigan, with strong winds within the warm sector leading to gusts up to 60 mph over Washtenaw and Wayne counties, causing a few downed trees and powerlines. A surface trough then initiated scattered severe thunderstorms which produced wind damage.

Late season melting of significant snow pack caused minor to moderate flooding across west and north central Upper Michigan from the 28th into 30th.  Gogebic County was hardest hit by the flooding where numerous primary and secondary roads were closed.  Snow melt flooding also impacted Ontonagon, Houghton, Keweenaw, Baraga and Marquette counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapid melting of significant late season snow pack caused moderate flooding of roads in the Bergland, Bruce Crossing and Rockland areas from the 28th into the 30th. Minor flooding continued into early May.  Some flooding of basements was also reported.  A portion of Highway M-28 was closed from Bergland to Bruce Crossing due to flooding.    Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in Ontonagon County where nearly $ 550,000 in property damage occurred due to the flooding mainly to roadway infrastructure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapid melting of significant late season snow pack caused minor to moerate flooding of Highway M-26 between Eagle River and Copper Harbor and along the Gay-Lac La Belle Road from the 28th into the 30th. Minor flooding continued into early May.  Some flooding of basements was also reported. Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in Keweenaw County where over $ 72,000 of property damage occurred due to the flooding mainly to roadway infrastructure.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines reported down.
