Late season melting of significant snow pack caused minor to moderate flooding across west and north central Upper Michigan from the 28th into 30th.  Gogebic County was hardest hit by the flooding where numerous primary and secondary roads were closed.  Snow melt flooding also impacted Ontonagon, Houghton, Keweenaw, Baraga and Marquette counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapid melting of significant late season snow pack caused moderate flooding of roads in the Ironwood, Bessemer, Wakefield and Marenisco areas from the 28th into the 30th. Minor flooding continued into early May.  Some flooding of basements was also reported.  A portion of Highway M-28 was closed in Wakefield due to flooding from Sunday Lake.  Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in Gogebic County where nearly one million dollars of property damage occurred due to the flooding mainly to roadway infrastructure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late season melting of significant snow pack caused minor to moderate flooding across west and north central Upper Michigan from the 28th into 30th.  Gogebic County was hardest hit by the flooding where numerous primary and secondary roads were closed.  Snow melt flooding also impacted Ontonagon, Houghton, Keweenaw, Baraga and Marquette counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapid melting of significant late season snow pack caused moderate flooding of roads across portions of Houghton County, especially along the Sturgeon River from Alston to Chassell, from the 28th into the 30th. Minor flooding continued into early May.  Some flooding of basements was also reported.  Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in Houghton County where nearly 2.9 million dollars in property damage occurred due to the flooding mainly to roadway infrastructure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving from the Plains through the Lower Great Lakes produced moderate snow over portions of northwest Upper Michigan on the morning of the 8th.  Dense fog occurred over portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the afternoon of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured 4.2 inches of snow in the early morning of the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving from the Plains through the Lower Great Lakes produced moderate snow over portions of northwest Upper Michigan on the morning of the 8th.  Dense fog occurred over portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the afternoon of the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Houghton County Airport reported visibility of one-quarter mile or less on the afternoon of the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Gladstone and near Rapid River measured around eight inches of wet snow in approximately 12 hours.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 12th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer ten miles east of Ontonagon measured 5.5 inches of wet snow in nine hours while the observer in Ontonagon measured nearly four inches of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township and the observer seven miles northeast of Ishpeming measured seven inches of wet snow in approximately 12 hours.   Storm total snowfall measured over ten inches at the National Weather Service.  The storm closed schools throughout the county on the 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Iowa across northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow over much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 11th into the morning of the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Redridge measured a storm total snowfall of 11.5 inches ending on the morning of the 13th.

A surface trough then initiated scattered severe thunderstorms which produced wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down.

A warm front lifted through Southeast Michigan, with strong winds within the warm sector leading to gusts up to 60 mph over Washtenaw and Wayne counties, causing a few downed trees and powerlines. A surface trough then initiated scattered severe thunderstorms which produced wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Shingles blown off roofs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving along a stalled cold front just east of Upper Michigan produced heavy snow and freezing rain over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 1st into the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Mohawk measured .2 inches of freezing rain on most surfaces, but roads and sidewalks were reportedly not slippery.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving along a stalled cold front just east of Upper Michigan produced heavy snow and freezing rain over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 1st into the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Houghton County Airport observed a light glaze of ice accumulation on the morning of the 2nd, but no travel problems were reported from the freezing rain.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving along a stalled cold front just east of Upper Michigan produced heavy snow and freezing rain over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 1st into the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Ironwood measured 11 inches of wet snow from the evening of the 1st into the afternoon of the 2nd.  A spotter near Bessemer estimated a storm total snowfall of 13 inches over approximately 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving along a stalled cold front just east of Upper Michigan produced heavy snow and freezing rain over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 1st into the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Ontonagon measured five inches of wet snow in six hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving along a stalled cold front just east of Upper Michigan produced heavy snow and freezing rain over portions of western Upper Michigan from the evening of the 1st into the 3rd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured 3.2 inches of wet snow which was also mixed with freezing rain and sleet at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Gladstone to Rapid River measured between four and five inches of wet snow in approximately ten hours.  Many area schools were closed on the 11th due to the wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer five miles north of Iron Mountain measured 4.8 inches of snow in approximately nine hours.  Many area schools were closed on the 11th due to the wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Herman and L'anse measured around six inches of wet snow in less than 12 hours.  Many area schools were closed due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 15 miles south of Wetmore measured 4.4 inches of snow in ten hours.  Many area schools were closed on the 11th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Stambaugh measured four inches of wet snow in eight hours.   Many area schools were closed on the 11th due to the wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured nearly 13 inches of snow in just nine hours.  There were several reports of seven to eight inches of snow in Ishpeming for the overnight period of the 10th into the morning 11th.  There was also a report of six inches of snow in Trowbridge Park in Marquette during the same period.  Many area schools were closed on the 11th due to the wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Redridge and Twin Lakes measured six inches of wet snow for the 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 11th.   Many area schools were closed on the 11th due to the wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from the Central Plains into northern Lower Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 10th into the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer eight miles west southwest of Ontonagon and a spotter near Paulding measured six inches of wet snow for the 12-hour period ending on the morning of the 11th.  Many area schools were closed on the 11th due to the wet snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Rockland and eight miles west southwest of Ontonagon measured 28 inches and 25 inches of respective storm total snowfall over a two-day period.   Many area schools were closed on the 19th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Late season melting of significant snow pack caused minor to moderate flooding across west and north central Upper Michigan from the 28th into 30th.  Gogebic County was hardest hit by the flooding where numerous primary and secondary roads were closed.  Snow melt flooding also impacted Ontonagon, Houghton, Keweenaw, Baraga and Marquette counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rapid melting of significant late season snow pack caused minor to moderate flooding of some secondary roads across portions of Marquette County from the 28th into the 30th. Minor flooding continued into early May.  Some flooding of basements was also reported. Governor Rick Snyder declared a state of disaster in Marquette County where nearly $ 625,000 of property damage occurred due to the flooding mainly to roadway infrastructure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters in Twin Lakes and Jacobsville measured 26 inches and 15.5 inches of respective storm total snowfall over a 38-hour time period.  Strong northwest wind gusting over 35 mph at times caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow with occasional whiteout conditions across northern Houghton County.  The storm forced the early dismissal of Houghton County Schools.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Newberry measured a storm total snowfall of 19 inches for the two and a half period ending on the morning of the 21st.   Northwest winds gusting to 35 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and occasional whiteout conditions.   Many area schools were closed on the 19th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system tracking from Minnesota into Ontario produced moderate snow over much of Upper Michigan from the 18th into the early morning hours of the 19th.  Gusty northwest winds behind the low brought in much colder air and generated a prolonged period of moderate to heavy lake effect snow in the northwest wind snow belts of west and north central Upper Michigan into the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters near Pelkie and L'anse measured 12 inches of storm total snowfall over approximately 40 hours while a spotter at Baraga measured 14 inches of snow over the same period.  Northwest winds gusting over 35 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and occasional whiteout conditions.  The storm forced the early dismissal of Baraga County Schools.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe weather struck portions of Southwest Lower Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of May 20th.  Damaging winds and large hail accompanied the strongest storms.  As the temperature and humidity levels climbed through the day, this led to a very unstable airmass in Michigan.  The arrival of a wave of low pressure triggered the storms shortly after noon.  As this feature tracked northeastward through Lower Michigan through the afternoon and evening, the storms strengthened and expanded in coverage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Mecosta county dispatch reported a downed tree brought down a couple of power lines near 8 mile road and US-131.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow moving, occluded low pressure system was nearly parked across the far northern Great Lakes.  A light synoptic snowfall gave way to more substantial lake effect snow during the day on the 19th.  By evening, snowfall totals were around a foot in areas just west of Traverse City (including Lake Ann, Leland, Interlochen, and Brethren).  Meanwhile, 6 to 8 inches of snow fell in the lake effect snow belts from Petoskey, to East Jordan, to near Gaylord.

Isolated severe storms caused wind gusts of up to 60 to 75 mph across portions of Ingham and Clinton counties on May 28th, with significant damage occurring to a lumberyard in Delta township in Clinton county where a semi was also blown over.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind damage at a lumberyard in Delta township and rolled a semi truck over as well. Several large tree limbs and branches were blown down near Dewitt. An old detached garage and a pole barn were damaged as well.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A batch of showers and thunderstorms came through on the 23rd and 24th bringing up to 2 inches of rain across the area. Flint and Saginaw set a record for wettest April on record.  Major flooding was reported along the Tittabawassee and Saginaw Rivers. Governor Synder declared Midland and Saginaw Counties disaster areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Tittawassee River at Midland crested at 28.37 feet on April 20th at 5Z.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper disturbances moving through a warm and unstable air mass produced several severe thunderstorms over western Upper Michigan during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 31th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees and a power line were knocked down in Bessemer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper disturbances moving through a warm and unstable air mass produced several severe thunderstorms over western Upper Michigan during the late afternoon and evening hours of the 31th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail was reported near Michigamme.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large and complex low pressure system lifted toward the southern and western Great Lakes region, bumping into high pressure over northern Ontario and Quebec.  The high helped anchor cold air in place at low levels, while warm and moist air surged in aloft ahead of the low.  This resulted in a wide mix of wintry precipitation, developing on the afternoon of the 11th, and ending late that night.  Eastern Upper Michigan was far enough north to get mostly snow, with up to nine inches measured in Pickford.  In northern Lower, snow transitioned to sleet and freezing rain, and in some places to just rain before dwindling.  Ice amounts were substantial near Saginaw Bay, with 3/4 of an inch of ice in parts of Gladwin County.  Trees and large limbs were downed, and power outages were common.  Another pocket of lighter ice accumulations, around a quarter of an inch, extended from the Grand Traverse Bay region, east to near Gaylord.

A powerful low pressure system strengthened and tracked northeast from the western Great Lakes towards James Bay during the afternoon of November 17th through the overnight hours. Southerly winds out ahead of the cold front allowed temperatures to soar into the lower to middle 60s during the afternoon hours across southeast Michigan. A line of thunderstorms developed with the cold front that swept through the area during the evening hours. Several of these storms produced severe wind gusts and wind damage as they moved through the area.  Behind the cold front, gradient winds gusted to 55 to 65 mph during the evening and overnight hours, producing additional damage across southeast Michigan. Widespread trees and power lines downed by the winds lead to over 400,000 homes and businesses to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An outbuilding was reported destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six of lake effect snow fell from McMillan to Newberry mainly in morning hours of the 20th.  Northwest winds gusting over 30 mph reduced visibility below one half mile at times in blowing snow.  There was also a report estimating seven inches of snow in eight hours at the Upper Tahquamenon Falls Brewery on the 21st.

The observer eight miles north of Mass City measured eight inches of lake effect snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An extended period of lake effect occurred in the northern Great Lakes, as the first of many very cold airmasses invaded. West-northwest winds resulted in a very long fetch across Lake Superior, resulting in locally heavy snow in central and western Chippewa County. Sault Ste Marie picked up nine inches of snow during the daylight hours of the 11th, and over the period from the 10th to the 12th, totals of one to two feet were common.

A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall rates reached up to two inches per hour at times, and twelve to fourteen inches of snow fell across Muskegon county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around ten to thirteen inches of snow fell across much of Newaygo county with highest totals reported over the southern third of Newaygo county where snowfall rates reached up to two inches per hour at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around ten inches of snow fell across most of Mecosta county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately nine to ten inches of snow fell across Isabella county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately eight to ten inches of snow fell across Osceola county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine to ten inches of snow fell across Clare county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees were downed, knocking down utility lines as well.  Old M-76 was closed for a period due to downed trees.  Shingles were removed from several homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered trees were downed in central Alcona County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado briefly touched down, and immediately crossed I-75, in extreme southern Otsego County. The tornado touched down just north of mile marker 268. Numerous evergreen and poplar trees were downed. Most trees were simply blown over, a few were snapped. Estimated peak wind speeds were 65 to 75 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts of just over two inches in an hour produced short-lived urban flooding in Cadillac. Numerous streets were impassible.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values were estimated between 25 to 30 below zero on both mornings of the 21st and 22nd.  Area schools were closed on the 22nd due to the extreme cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Delta County Airport AWOS reported wind chill values to 25 to 30 below zero on both mornings of the 21st and 22nd.  Area schools were closed on the 22nd due to the extreme cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Luce County Airport ASOS reported wind chill values to 25 to 30 below zero on the mornings of the 22nd.  Area schools were closed on the 22nd due to the extreme cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values were estimated between 25 and 30 below zero on the morning of the 22nd. Area schools were closed on the 22nd due to the extreme cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values were estimated between 25 and 30 below zero from the evening of the 21st into the morning of the 22nd...mainly over the western portion of the county.  Area schools were closed on the 22nd due to the extreme cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Manistique AWOS measured wind chill values between 25 and 30 below zero from the evening of the 21st into the morning of the 22nd. Area schools were closed on the 22nd due to the extreme cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Twin Lakes measured 18 inches of lake effect snow over 48 hours.  Northwest wind gusts to 40 mph accompanying the lake effect snow also reduced visibility to one-quarter mile at times in blowing snow from the evening of the 19th into the early morning of the 20th.  There was also a report from Houghton of eight inches in 24 hours with a brief period of over one inch per hour snowfall rates on the morning of the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Redridge measured ten inches of snow in 24 hours, and there was a report of 8.4 inches in 11 hours at South Range.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low pressure system strengthened and tracked northeast from the western Great Lakes towards James Bay during the afternoon of November 17th through the overnight hours. Southerly winds out ahead of the cold front allowed temperatures to soar into the lower to middle 60s during the afternoon hours across southeast Michigan. A line of thunderstorms developed with the cold front that swept through the area during the evening hours. Several of these storms produced severe wind gusts and wind damage as they moved through the area.  Behind the cold front, gradient winds gusted to 55 to 65 mph during the evening and overnight hours, producing additional damage across southeast Michigan. Widespread trees and power lines downed by the winds lead to over 400,000 homes and businesses to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few 4 to 5 inch diameter trees were reported blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree fell onto a house.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Ironwood estimated four to five inches of lake effect snow in five hours with whiteout conditions in heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper system moving through the area brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 25th.  The heaviest snow was over Luce and Schoolcraft counties where lake enhancement off Lake Michigan boosted snow totals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of an estimated 15 inches of snow in approximately 15 hours from seven miles south of Newberry.  There was also a report 14 inches of snow near McMillan in 22 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper system moving through the area brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 25th.  The heaviest snow was over Luce and Schoolcraft counties where lake enhancement off Lake Michigan boosted snow totals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters over the southern portion of the county measured four to six inches of snow in 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper system moving through the area brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 25th.  The heaviest snow was over Luce and Schoolcraft counties where lake enhancement off Lake Michigan boosted snow totals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Menominee County Emergency Manager measured 3.5 to 4.0 inches of snow in the city of Menominee over approximately 15 hours.  Slippery roads were reported throughout the southern half of the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper system moving through the area brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 25th.  The heaviest snow was over Luce and Schoolcraft counties where lake enhancement off Lake Michigan boosted snow totals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Just over three inches of snow was reported northeast of Iron Mountain in approximately 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A clipper system moving through the area brought moderate to heavy snow to portions of south central and eastern Upper Michigan on the 25th.  The heaviest snow was over Luce and Schoolcraft counties where lake enhancement off Lake Michigan boosted snow totals.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter 20 miles north of Iron River measured 5.2 inches of snow in approximately 15 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated 12 inches of snow in 24 hours near Au Train ending on the morning of February 1st.  It was still snowing heavily on the morning of the 1st at the time of the report.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Lower Great Lakes produced moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 27th into the morning of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Bessemer estimated six inches of snow fell in 12 hours while a spotter near Ironwood measured nearly seven inches of snow in 14 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold air flowing across Lake Michigan ahead of low pressure trough moving through the Upper Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy enhanced snow to east central Upper Michigan from late on the 24th into the 25th.  A strong west to northwest flow of cold air behind this trough passage also brought moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow to portions of west and northeast Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter four miles east of Silver City measured 16.5 inches of lake effect snow in just over 14 hours with frequent one inch per hour snowfall rates.  One inch per hour snowfall rates were also reported in Ontonagon on Christmas afternoon with nearly eight inches of snow.  Over eight inches of lake effect snow fell just north of Mass City for the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 26th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter estimated a 60 mph thunderstorm wind gust.

A low pressure system moving through the Lower Great Lakes produced moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 27th into the morning of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters from Bark River to Gladstone and Stonington measured four inches of snow in just over 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system moving through the Lower Great Lakes produced moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 27th into the morning of the 28th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Menominee measured three inches of snow in six hours.  Roads were reported to be snow covered and slippery into the morning of the 28th.  As a result, Menominee schools were closed on the 28th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: East winds on the northern fringes of a low pressure system crossing the Lower Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Menominee and Delta counties from the 14th into the morning of the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Fayette measured 12.8 inches of lake enhanced snow in approximately ten hours on the 14th with snowfall rates exceeding two inches per hour at times.  The observer near Stonington measured eight inches of snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 15th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: East winds on the northern fringes of a low pressure system crossing the Lower Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow to portions of Menominee and Delta counties from the 14th into the morning of the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 4.5 inches of lake enhanced snow in approximately eight hours five miles east of Stephenson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper disturbance from south central Canada produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of northwest and north central Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A location near Twin Lakes measured 12 inches of lake effect snow in 27 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper disturbance from south central Canada produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of northwest and north central Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated ten inches of lake enhanced snow in 12 hours in the Marquette area west of Trowbridge Park on Neejee Road.  Nearly seven inches of snow fell at the National Weather Service in Negaunee Township during the same time.  Intense snow and blowing of snow caused whiteout conditions at times in the Marquette area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold arctic air brought a drastic temperature change during the early morning hours of February 19th which was followed by lake effect snow that quickly developed and lasted into the 20th.  Hardest hit were areas from around Muskegon south to Saugatuck, where around 10 to 12 inches of snow fell. The snow fell over the course of two days and only some minor slow downs on roadways were noted as impacts from this snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Approximately six to eight inches of snow fell across most of Mason county over a two day period. Low travel impacts noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold arctic air brought a drastic temperature change during the early morning hours of February 19th which was followed by lake effect snow that quickly developed and lasted into the 20th.  Hardest hit were areas from around Muskegon south to Saugatuck, where around 10 to 12 inches of snow fell. The snow fell over the course of two days and only some minor slow downs on roadways were noted as impacts from this snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across roughly the northwestern quarter of Allegan county, with lesser amounts elsewhere. Low impacts were noted as this snow fell slowly over the course of two days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow began on January 20th and continued all the way through January 24th, primarily impacting the Lake Michigan shoreline counties and areas west of US-131 with the heaviest snow amounts and totals.  Cumulative snowfall amounts for this event reached as high as twenty inches in Allendale in Ottawa county, with many locations across the lakeshore counties reporting over a foot of snow. Strong Winds occurred before the snow on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Around one foot of snow fell across far eastern Kalamazoo County. Most of this fell in a twelve hour period on January 21 and resulted in Moderate travel impacts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow began on January 20th and continued all the way through January 24th, primarily impacting the Lake Michigan shoreline counties and areas west of US-131 with the heaviest snow amounts and totals.  Cumulative snowfall amounts for this event reached as high as twenty inches in Allendale in Ottawa county, with many locations across the lakeshore counties reporting over a foot of snow. Strong Winds occurred before the snow on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to 12 inches of snow was reported in portions of Mason County. A 57 mph wind was recorded at Big Sable Point before the onset of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper disturbance from south central Canada produced moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow over portions of northwest and north central Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Eben Junction measured 3.5 inches of lake enhanced snow in three hours along with blowing and drifting of snow.  Observers measured around six inches of snow in Munising and south of Grand Marais over 24 hours.

Cold arctic air brought a drastic temperature change during the early morning hours of February 19th which was followed by lake effect snow that quickly developed and lasted into the 20th.  Hardest hit were areas from around Muskegon south to Saugatuck, where around 10 to 12 inches of snow fell. The snow fell over the course of two days and only some minor slow downs on roadways were noted as impacts from this snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across the western half of Ottawa county. This snow fell slowly over the course of two days and only low travel impacts were noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow began on January 20th and continued all the way through January 24th, primarily impacting the Lake Michigan shoreline counties and areas west of US-131 with the heaviest snow amounts and totals.  Cumulative snowfall amounts for this event reached as high as twenty inches in Allendale in Ottawa county, with many locations across the lakeshore counties reporting over a foot of snow. Strong Winds occurred before the snow on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to 12 inches of snow fell across Oceana County with Moderate travel impacts. Most of this snow fell in a twelve hour period early on January 21. Peak wind gusts to around 65 mph were estimated and caused reports of several downed trees and power lines across Oceana county prior to the onset of snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper dropped between 2 and 4 inches of accumulating snow on the region, with heavier amounts in excess of 6 inches near the Lake Michigan shoreline in southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow covered roads led to a few accidents and slide-offs across the region on February 2nd as light to moderate snow fell for much of the day. Total snow accumulations ranged between 3 and 6 inches across southeast Berrien County to between 6 and 12 inches elsewhere. There was a report of 11 inches of total snow accumulation in Benton Harbor. Interstate 94 was closed during the day from Coloma to Van Buren. There were no serious injuries or accidents reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta Clipper dropped between 2 and 4 inches of accumulating snow on the region, with heavier amounts in excess of 6 inches near the Lake Michigan shoreline in southwest Lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow covered roads led to a few accidents and slide-offs across the region on February 2nd as light to moderate snow fell for much of the day. Total snow accumulations ranged between 2 and 5 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another bout of lake effect snow, thanks to cold north-northwest winds. Lake effect snow was heavy at times in Grand Traverse, western Kalkaska, and western Antrim Counties, especially on the night of the 26th. Snowfall amounts of 8 to 12 inches were common, with Central Lake receiving the largest amount at 12 inches.

A prolonged Lake Effect Snow Event began late on January 31st with impacts being first felt midday February 1st.  S0me locations saw continuous snow for 72 hours, though the greatest impacts were felt from midday to midnight February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Far western Kent County received up to 15 inches of snow. Mainly west of US 131 with moderate travel impacts and some power outages reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged Lake Effect Snow Event began late on January 31st with impacts being first felt midday February 1st.  S0me locations saw continuous snow for 72 hours, though the greatest impacts were felt from midday to midnight February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Southern half of the county and especially the southeast portion of the county received up to one foot of snow. Moderate travel impacts and some power outages were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across Ottawa county with the highest totals of around a foot across northern Ottawa county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall rates reached two inches per hour at times across northern Kenty county.  Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across central and northern Kent county, with the highest totals of around a foot across northern Kent county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to eleven inches of snow fell across central and northern Montcalm county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low pressure system strengthened and tracked northeast from the western Great Lakes towards James Bay during the afternoon of November 17th through the overnight hours. Southerly winds out ahead of the cold front allowed temperatures to soar into the lower to middle 60s during the afternoon hours across southeast Michigan. A line of thunderstorms developed with the cold front that swept through the area during the evening hours. Several of these storms produced severe wind gusts and wind damage as they moved through the area.  Behind the cold front, gradient winds gusted to 55 to 65 mph during the evening and overnight hours, producing additional damage across southeast Michigan. Widespread trees and power lines downed by the winds lead to over 400,000 homes and businesses to lose power.

A low pressure system brought up to ten to fourteen inches of snow to portions of central lower Michigan with snowfall rates of up to two inches per hour at times.  The heaviest snow fell from Muskegon east northeast to Big Rapids and Mt. Pleasant.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to ten inches of snow fell across northern Gratiot county.

A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Sidnaw estimated nearly five inches of snow in less than 24 hours.  Freezing rain was also reported for several hours on the afternoon of the 4th resulting in several accidents.

A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two to four inches of widespread snowfall was reported throughout the county.  There was a period of freezing rain and sleet on the afternoon of the 4th.  Several accidents were reported throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread three to five inches of wet snow fell in less than 24 hours throughout much of the county.  A period of sleet and freezing rain on the morning of the 4th also contributed to several accidents throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow began on January 20th and continued all the way through January 24th, primarily impacting the Lake Michigan shoreline counties and areas west of US-131 with the heaviest snow amounts and totals.  Cumulative snowfall amounts for this event reached as high as twenty inches in Allendale in Ottawa county, with many locations across the lakeshore counties reporting over a foot of snow. Strong Winds occurred before the snow on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Muskegon county official reported that a general 12 to 16 inches of snow had fallen across much of the county during this event. Up to 10 inches of this fell in a twelve hour period on January 21. A 65 mph peak wind gust was recorded at the Muskegon GLERL coastal site on the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow began on January 20th and continued all the way through January 24th, primarily impacting the Lake Michigan shoreline counties and areas west of US-131 with the heaviest snow amounts and totals.  Cumulative snowfall amounts for this event reached as high as twenty inches in Allendale in Ottawa county, with many locations across the lakeshore counties reporting over a foot of snow. Strong Winds occurred before the snow on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A lake effect storm total snowfall of twenty inches was reported by a CoCoRaHS observer in Allendale. A 67 mph peak wind gust was recorded at the Grand Haven Steelheaders coastal site on the 19th.  Strong winds did not extend far inland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread five to seven inches of wet snow was reported across much of the county in less than 24 hours.  A period of sleet and freezing rain was also reported during the afternoon of the 4th.  Numerous accidents were reported throughout the area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers reported a widespread two to three inches of wet snow over 24 hours.  Some sleet and freezing rain were also reported on the morning of the 4th which contributed to slippery roadways.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting up from the Southern Plains brought moderate snow mixed with sleet and freezing rain to much of west and central Upper Michigan from late on the 3rd through the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in the Ontonagon area measured nearly four inches of snow in less than 24 hours.  Four hours of sleet and freezing rain on top of the snow created treacherous driving conditions.  Numerous accidents were reported throughout the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold arctic air brought a drastic temperature change during the early morning hours of February 19th which was followed by lake effect snow that quickly developed and lasted into the 20th.  Hardest hit were areas from around Muskegon south to Saugatuck, where around 10 to 12 inches of snow fell. The snow fell over the course of two days and only some minor slow downs on roadways were noted as impacts from this snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to twelve inches of snow fell across much of Muskegon county. Low travel impacts were noted as snow fell slowly over the course of two days.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through Upper Michigan produced heavy snow over the east half of Upper Michigan on the 30th, and then moderate to heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow behind the front into the 31st for portions of west and north central Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Mohawk measured 11 inches of snow in 36 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter in Ironwood estimated three to four inches of snow in three hours.  The snow was moderate to heavy at the time of the observation.

Strong Winds occurred before the snow on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A general 12 inches of snow fell across Allegan County with up to 18 inches total for the event reported.  Most of this snow fell in a 12 hour period early on January 21. Moderate travel impacts were reported. Peak wind gusts to around 65 mph resulted in several reports of downed trees and power lines across Allegan county on the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow began on January 20th and continued all the way through January 24th, primarily impacting the Lake Michigan shoreline counties and areas west of US-131 with the heaviest snow amounts and totals.  Cumulative snowfall amounts for this event reached as high as twenty inches in Allendale in Ottawa county, with many locations across the lakeshore counties reporting over a foot of snow. Strong Winds occurred before the snow on the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to eighteen inches of snow fell during this event. Up to 10 inches of snow fell in a twelve hour period early on January 21. A 62 mph peak wind gust was recorded at the South Haven GLERL coastal site on the 19th before snow started. Winds did not extend inland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were downed over roads in western Gladwin County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful low pressure system strengthened and tracked northeast from the western Great Lakes towards James Bay during the afternoon of November 17th through the overnight hours. Southerly winds out ahead of the cold front allowed temperatures to soar into the lower to middle 60s during the afternoon hours across southeast Michigan. A line of thunderstorms developed with the cold front that swept through the area during the evening hours. Several of these storms produced severe wind gusts and wind damage as they moved through the area.  Behind the cold front, gradient winds gusted to 55 to 65 mph during the evening and overnight hours, producing additional damage across southeast Michigan. Widespread trees and power lines downed by the winds lead to over 400,000 homes and businesses to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A Kohls sign was reported blown down, as well as damage to a gas station awning.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Au Train estimated five inches of lake effect snow in less than six hours on the 20th. Strong northwest winds with gusts over 30 mph caused whiteout conditions in snow and blowing snow along M-28.  There was also a report estimating 14-16 inches in Munising over a 36-hour period ending on the morning of the 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An Alberta clipper system ushered bitter cold Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes during the period.  The bitter cold air mass also helped sustain periods of moderate to heavy lake effect snow over several days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of lake effect snow fell in the morning hours on the 20th.  Northwest wind gusting over 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and reduced visibility to one quarter mile at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong low pressure system continued to intensify as it moved northeast across the Great Lakes region November 17th and 18th.  The system brought a round of severe thunderstorms during the afternoon hours of Sunday the 17th, followed by very strong winds in the 60 to 80 mph range Sunday evening and Sunday night.  Some of the strongest winds occurred between 8 pm and midnight on the 17th.  South Haven had a peak wind gust of 77 mph and a 63 mph gust was recorded at Grand Rapids.  This caused hundreds of thousands of power outages across lower Michigan as numerous trees, limbs and power lines were blown down.  In some of the more rural areas, power was not restored for four to five days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph caused numerous power outages in Muskegon county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong low pressure system continued to intensify as it moved northeast across the Great Lakes region November 17th and 18th.  The system brought a round of severe thunderstorms during the afternoon hours of Sunday the 17th, followed by very strong winds in the 60 to 80 mph range Sunday evening and Sunday night.  Some of the strongest winds occurred between 8 pm and midnight on the 17th.  South Haven had a peak wind gust of 77 mph and a 63 mph gust was recorded at Grand Rapids.  This caused hundreds of thousands of power outages across lower Michigan as numerous trees, limbs and power lines were blown down.  In some of the more rural areas, power was not restored for four to five days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A measured wind gust of 63 mph was recorded at Gerald Ford Airport in Grand Rapids at 8:12 pm and wind gusts generally in the 60 to 70 mph range caused widespread power outages in Kent county.  At one point well over 30,000 people in Kent county were without power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large line of thunderstorms weakened as it moved off of Lake Michigan into northern Lower Michigan, but still produced a touch of wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered pockets of downed trees and power lines occurred in western Leelanau County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong low pressure system continued to intensify as it moved northeast across the Great Lakes region November 17th and 18th. Some of the strongest winds occurred between 8 pm and midnight on the 17th.  South Haven had a peak wind gust of 77 mph and a 63 mph gust was recorded at Grand Rapids.  This caused hundreds of thousands of power outages across lower Michigan as numerous trees, limbs and power lines were blown down.  In some of the more rural areas, power was not restored for four to five days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph across Kalamazoo county resulted in thousands of power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Central Plains tracked northeast near the Mackinac Straits and produced moderate wet snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 5th into the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters near Trout Creek and Paulding measured between four and five inches of wet snow over a 24-hour period.  Slushy and slippery roads contributed to several minor traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northwest winds in the wake of cold front produced moderate lake effect snow showers over portions of west and east central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th to the morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Bergland Dam measured 3.6 inches of lake effect snow in approximately 10 hours.  Slippery roads contributed to several minor traffic accidents.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong low pressure system continued to intensify as it moved northeast across the Great Lakes region November 17th and 18th.  The system brought a round of severe thunderstorms during the afternoon hours of Sunday the 17th, followed by very strong winds in the 60 to 80 mph range Sunday evening and Sunday night.  Some of the strongest winds occurred between 8 pm and midnight on the 17th.  South Haven had a peak wind gust of 77 mph and a 63 mph gust was recorded at Grand Rapids.  This caused hundreds of thousands of power outages across lower Michigan as numerous trees, limbs and power lines were blown down.  In some of the more rural areas, power was not restored for four to five days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 77 mph peak non-thunderstorm wind gust was measured at the South Haven GLERL coastal site.  60 to 75 mph wind gusts were common across Van Buren county during the evening hours, resulting in thousands of power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous reports of wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph and widespread power outages were received from Barry county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm in northwest Lower Michigan produced wind damage and marginally large hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were downed, one of which crushed a vehicle. Crystal Springs Road was blocked by downed trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple thunderstorms moved over portions of the upper St Marys River valley on the night of the 9th. Most of the heavy rain fell on the Canadian side of the border, but the swath of excessive rain did cross the north half of Sugar Island.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Radar estimated that 3 to 5 inches of rain fell in a few hours beginning late in the evening of the 9th, resulting in flash flood in the pre-dawn hours of the 10th.  A number of roads were washed out and/or otherwise rendered impassable, in some cases for several days. West Shore Drive, and 1 1/2 Mile Road, were among the roads that suffered considerable damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Central Plains tracked northeast near the Mackinac Straits and produced moderate wet snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 5th into the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer near Ironwood measured 3.5 inches of wet snow in approximately 12 hours.   Slushy and slippery roads contributed to several minor traffic accidents.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph caused widespread power outages in Gratiot county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong low pressure system continued to intensify as it moved northeast across the Great Lakes region November 17th and 18th.  The system brought a round of severe thunderstorms during the afternoon hours of Sunday the 17th, followed by very strong winds in the 60 to 80 mph range Sunday evening and Sunday night.  Some of the strongest winds occurred between 8 pm and midnight on the 17th.  South Haven had a peak wind gust of 77 mph and a 63 mph gust was recorded at Grand Rapids.  This caused hundreds of thousands of power outages across lower Michigan as numerous trees, limbs and power lines were blown down.  In some of the more rural areas, power was not restored for four to five days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts of 60 to 70 mph caused numerous power outages in Newaygo county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong warm front surged north into Lower Michigan during the early morning hours of the 9th. Steep lapse rates and abundant lift with the front along allowed for several rounds of showers and a few thunderstorms to persist across portions of far southern Lower Michigan. Reports of four to over five inches of rain were received across portions of Hillsdale County, especially in the Litchfield area where several roads were flooded and impassable.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads were flooded in and around Litchfield and Hillsdale with ditches filled and several yards under water. A CoCoRAHs observer reported 5.35 inches of rain from the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of November 17th in advance of a strong cold front.  The storms blew down and uprooted numerous trees across lower Michigan, caused numerous power outages, significant straight line wind damage and even several brief weak EF-0 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced a measured wind gust of 62 mph at the Muskegon GLERL site.  There were several reports of downed trees and power lines across Muskegon county.  In Canada Corners, seven light poles were blown down and several large trees were snapped or uprooted at Moss Ridge golf course.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of November 17th in advance of a strong cold front.  The storms blew down and uprooted numerous trees across lower Michigan, caused numerous power outages, significant straight line wind damage and even several brief weak EF-0 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS storm survey indicated that microburst straight line wind damage with maximum winds of 75 mph caused part of the roof of Mattawan high school to be torn off.  Several trees were blown down and awning and roof damage was also incurred at an apartment.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of November 17th in advance of a strong cold front.  The storms blew down and uprooted numerous trees across lower Michigan, caused numerous power outages, significant straight line wind damage and even several brief weak EF-0 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported power lines were blown down in Grand Haven.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported one inch diameter hail near Monterey.  A trained spotter in Dorr reported a measured wind gust of 65 mph.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a measured wind gust of 63 mph in Byron Center.  A 59 mph gust was reported at East Grand Rapids high school and several other spotters reported gusts to around 60 mph and downed tree limbs and power lines.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An amateur radio operator reported significant tree and structural damage on 80th avenue between M20 and Garfield.  Boats were also flipped in a boat yard.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front generated moderate lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior from the 22nd into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Forest Lake estimated six inches of lake effect snow in less than 18 hours.  The spotter reported that travel was becoming difficult on Highway M-94 due to the snow.  Another spotter in Eben Junction estimated four inches of snow over approximately the same time period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front generated moderate lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior from the 22nd into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall over a 36-hour period included 6.0 inches 15 miles south of Wetmore, 7.1 inches in Munising and 8.6 inches ten miles south of Grand Marais.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A surge of Arctic air in the wake of a strong cold front generated moderate lake effect snow showers downwind of Lake Superior from the 22nd into the 24th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms developed during the afternoon hours of November 17th in advance of a strong cold front.  The storms blew down and uprooted numerous trees across lower Michigan, caused numerous power outages, significant straight line wind damage and even several brief weak EF-0 tornadoes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced multiple brief EF-0 tornadoes along a more than 50 mile path from Muskegon county northeast through Newaygo county into Mecosta county. The tornadoes were on the ground for very short periods of time. Mostly tree damage was incurred but there was also damage to several buildings and fences.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of downed trees and power lines resulting from scattered severe thunderstorms on July 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that numerous power lines and trees were blown down in Milwood and fairly extensive wind damage was reported across portions of Kalamazoo county.  A 59 mph wind gust was measured at Kalamazoo airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Microburst straight line wind damage impacted downtown Albion on September 11th, where maximum winds were estimated at 70 to 80 mph.  The worst damage occurred along a path one and three quarters mile long and up to a half a mile wide where numerous trees and power lines were blown down.  Albion college was shut down for several days due to all the wind damage and lack of power.  Isolated damaging wind gusts from severe storms were reported elsewhere during the late afternoon hours of September 11th, and there was also an isolated severe storm that produced one inch diameter hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported one inch diameter hail near Tompkins Center.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isolated trees and limbs were blown down in southern Jackson county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Ingham county central dispatch reported that several trees were blown down in and near Stockbridge as a severe storm drifted north into southern Ingham county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced 1 inch diameter hail near Manchester.
Up to 3 inches of rain falling in about an hour lead to water covered roads, up to a foot.
Showers with an isolated thunderstorm developed over Metro Detroit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were reported blown down, one of which fell onto a woman who broke her leg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains moved across the Upper Great Lakes and brought moderate lake enhanced snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 21st into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observers at Jacobsville and near Redridge measured between four and five inches of wet lake enhanced snow over the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 22nd.  There was a public report from Painesdale which also estimated between four and five inches of snow during the same period.  Several minor traffic accidents were reported due to the wet slushy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several large trees were blown down by scattered severe storms that impacted portions of south central lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A county official reported that multiple large trees were blown down near Wiley. This storm also brought down scattered branches in Lake and Newaygo Counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: There were several reports of downed trees and power lines resulting from scattered severe thunderstorms on July 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees and power lines were blown down in Leroy Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Isabella county emergency management reported that many mid to large size tree branches were blown down with power outages.  Several power poles were blown down as well.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported several trees were blown down across portions of Ottawa county.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Kent county law enforcement reported that several trees were blown down across portions of Kent county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Microburst straight line wind damage impacted downtown Albion on September 11th, where maximum winds were estimated at 70 to 80 mph.  The worst damage occurred along a path one and three quarters mile long and up to a half a mile wide where numerous trees and power lines were blown down.  Albion college was shut down for several days due to all the wind damage and lack of power.  Isolated damaging wind gusts from severe storms were reported elsewhere during the late afternoon hours of September 11th, and there was also an isolated severe storm that produced one inch diameter hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A severe thunderstorm produced wind gusts of up to 70 to 80 mph that brought down numerous trees and power lines in and near Albion, resulting in numerous power outages and a closure of Albion college for several days due to all the wind damage and loss of power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms crossed northern Michigan during the morning hours.  Additional thunderstorm development occurred behind that line in the late afternoon and evening. These storms produced some severe weather in northeast Lower Michigan.

A line of thunderstorms crossed northern Michigan during the morning hours.  Additional thunderstorm development occurred behind that line in the late afternoon and evening. These storms produced some severe weather in northeast Lower Michigan.
There were several reports of downed trees and power lines resulting from scattered severe thunderstorms on July 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees and power lines were blown down across portions of Calhoun county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Damaging wind gusts occurred due to an isolated severe thunderstorm that impacted portions of Jackson county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple of trees were blown down by an isolated severe thunderstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Relief from a 6 day Heat Wave came in the form of a slow moving cold front, which triggered multiple rounds of severe thunderstorms across Southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of July 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple large trees and power lines down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Relief from a 6 day Heat Wave came in the form of a slow moving cold front, which triggered multiple rounds of severe thunderstorms across Southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of July 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six inch diameter tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms brought down several trees across a few counties in southwest lower Michigan and resulted in a peak wind gust of 68 mph at the Kalamazoo airport.  There was also an isolated reported of one inch diameter hail in Kenty county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Law enforcement reported multiple trees were blown down in the 7200 block of Blue Lake road and White Lake road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One inch hail was reported with a couple of thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon hours.
One inch hail was reported with a couple of thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon hours.
One inch hail was reported with a couple of thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon hours.
Two weak tornadoes developed in Southern Livingston County from the same thunderstorm that was moving along a boundary that was over the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous hardwood and softwood trees were uprooted and snapped with this EF0 tornado. Maximum winds estimated at 80 mph. The tornado touched down near Betterly Road, tracking East, then hooking Southeast to Northeast, tracking across Byron Road before lifting just before Oak Grove Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two weak tornadoes developed in Southern Livingston County from the same thunderstorm that was moving along a boundary that was over the county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous hardwood and softwood trees were uprooted and snapped. Minor siding damage was also observed with this EF0 tornado with maximum winds of 80 mph. The tornado touched down near the Brighton Road and Timberline Lane intersection, tracking southeast and lifting just past the Welle Road and Hamell Road intersection.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rainfall of 2 to 3 inches fell within a couple of hours leading some Flash Flooding within the Detroit Metro Area. Generally from Birmingham to Eight Mile and Telegraph and into Southwest Macomb County. In addition, isolated severe thunderstorms occurred over Sandusky in Sanilac County and near Romulus in Wayne County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A couple feet of water was covering area roads.
