EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system originating over the Plains moved across the Upper Great Lakes and brought moderate lake enhanced snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 21st into the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Most spotters in Gogebic County reported between two and three inches of lake enhanced snow on the morning of the 23rd.  However...there was one public report of an estimated five to six inches of snow near Bessemer.  Several minor accidents were reported due to the wet slushy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms that impacted eastern Wisconsin with wind gusts of up to 80 mph during the early morning hours on August 7th diminished somewhat as they crossed Lake Michigan, but still produced reports of 60 to 70 mph wind gusts and some damage from Big Sable Point east southeast to Evart.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake county emergency management reported that numerous trees were blown down throughout Lake county with widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms that impacted eastern Wisconsin with wind gusts of up to 80 mph during the early morning hours on August 7th diminished somewhat as they crossed Lake Michigan, but still produced reports of 60 to 70 mph wind gusts and some damage from Big Sable Point east southeast to Evart.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that multiple trees were blown down just west of Evart and across portions of Osceola county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms that impacted eastern Wisconsin with wind gusts of up to 80 mph during the early morning hours on August 7th diminished somewhat as they crossed Lake Michigan, but still produced reports of 60 to 70 mph wind gusts and some damage from Big Sable Point east southeast to Evart.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 61 mph measured gust was reported by a mesonet station at Big Sable Point and several trees were blown down across portions of Mason county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Gusty northwesterly winds moved across Lake Michigan in the wake of a strong cold front. Wave heights of three to six feet were common during the afternoon hours of the 27th. A 15 year old boy from Illinois was caught in a rip current and pulled away from shore. He was rescued and airlifted to a Chicago hospital, where he died several hours later.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 15 year old boy was roughly 100 feet offshore from a New Buffalo public beach when he was caught in a rip current.  The rip current pulled him away from shore. Lifeguards quickly noticed the problem and were able to rescue the boy and perform CPR. He has transported to a local hospital and then airlifted to a Chicago hospital, where he died later that evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Relief from a 6 day Heat Wave came in the form of a slow moving cold front, which triggered multiple rounds of severe thunderstorms across Southeast Michigan during the afternoon and evening hours of July 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Disorganized clusters of thunderstorms developed in the afternoon, in a warm and rather humid airmass.  Some of these storms became severe.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Over forty trees were downed in Clear Lake State Park.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The passage of a cold front through a very warm and unstable air mass generated scattered severe thunderstorms across portions of west and central Upper Michigan on the afternoon of the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quarter-sized hail was reported at Eben Junction.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper trough deepening over the Great Lakes generated thunderstorms with heavy rain over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 25th into the 26th. Some of the storms turned severe over Gogebic and Dickinson counties on the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were knocked down or snapped just north of the Wisconsin border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifted through Southeast Michigan, with strong winds within the warm sector leading to gusts up to 60 mph over Washtenaw and Wayne counties, causing a few downed trees and powerlines. A surface trough then initiated scattered severe thunderstorms which produced wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree blown down, along with a reported damaged chimney.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front spawned 6 tornadoes which impacted Shiawassee and Genesee Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado was rated EF2 with a maximum wind speed of 130 mph. The maximum path width was 300 yards with a total path length of 4.6 miles. The tornado started near the intersection of Vassar Road and Pointe North Drive and continued to State Road near Perry Road. The greatest damage occurred near the intersection of Hegel Gale Roads. A house was nearly destroyed, along with a garage and external storage facilities wrecked.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Several severe thunderstorms developed with good afternoon instability.
A strong cold front swept through the region interacting with a strongly sheared, moderately unstable environment. Numerous thunderstorms developed rapidly and produced isolated wind damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported a tree of unknown size across a local road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long and narrow line of thunderstorms produced isolated wind damage as it crossed eastern Upper Michigan.
Several severe thunderstorms developed with good afternoon instability.
Several supercells developed during the late afternon and early evening hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was snapped in half.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered severe thunderstorms developed, with Oakland and Washtenaw Counties being hardest hit, where flash flooding also occured.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 1.5 foot diameter tree was blown down across Waldon Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An unusual November severe weather outbreak - including an extremely rare tornado - impacted northern Michigan.  Thunderstorms ignited along and ahead of a strong cold front that crossed the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Rainfall amounts of just over two inches in an hour produced short-lived urban flooding in Traverse City. Numerous streets were impassible, including Veterans Drive, Garfield Road, and South Airport Road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance moved through the region during the late afternoon and early evening hours. Strong shear, instability and steep mid level lapse rates all combined with the wave to produce numerous thunderstorms. The storms moved off southern Lake Michigan and continued to expand and intensify as they moved east. Several reports of damaging winds were received along with some hail.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Emergency management officials reported numerous power lines down from strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance interacted with an unstable airmass in place across Lower Michigan, producing multiple short line segments of strong to severe thunderstorms.  These storms produced both large hail and damaging wind gusts during the afternoon hours.

A powerful low pressure system strengthened and tracked northeast from the western Great Lakes towards James Bay during the afternoon of November 17th through the overnight hours. Southerly winds out ahead of the cold front allowed temperatures to soar into the lower to middle 60s during the afternoon hours across southeast Michigan. A line of thunderstorms developed with the cold front that swept through the area during the evening hours. Several of these storms produced severe wind gusts and wind damage as they moved through the area.  Behind the cold front, gradient winds gusted to 55 to 65 mph during the evening and overnight hours, producing additional damage across southeast Michigan. Widespread trees and power lines downed by the winds lead to over 400,000 homes and businesses to lose power.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dispatched reported multiple tree downs throughout Midland County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving slowly across the region served as the focus for severe thunderstorms over portions of Upper Michigan from the evening of the 18th into the afternoon of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Penny to nickel-sized hail was reported along with 40 mph wind gusts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure moved across the northern Great Lakes, with a strong cold front trailing well south into Arkansas. A 50 to 60 knot low level jet aided in advecting in dewpoints greater than 60 degrees. 0-1km storm relative helicity values of 400 to 600 m2/s2 setup the perfect environment for individual thunderstorms to rapidly rotate with the lower values into far southern Lower Michigan. While favorable conditions existed, the area was just far enough north of the best conditions to keep the most severe weather away. However, isolated wind damage and one tornado was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported seven power poles were snapped. Other damage included the roof torn off a small shed and several center pivots being damaged. A snowmobile trailer was lifted and then tossed 100 yards.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure moved across the northern Great Lakes, with a strong cold front trailing well south into Arkansas. A 50 to 60 knot low level jet aided in advecting in dewpoints greater than 60 degrees. 0-1km storm relative helicity values of 400 to 600 m2/s2 setup the perfect environment for individual thunderstorms to rapidly rotate with the lower values into far southern Lower Michigan. While favorable conditions existed, the area was just far enough north of the best conditions to keep the most severe weather away. However, isolated wind damage and one tornado was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported several trees down near Union Lake.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure moved across the northern Great Lakes, with a strong cold front trailing well south into Arkansas. A 50 to 60 knot low level jet aided in advecting in dewpoints greater than 60 degrees. 0-1km storm relative helicity values of 400 to 600 m2/s2 setup the perfect environment for individual thunderstorms to rapidly rotate with the lower values into far southern Lower Michigan. While favorable conditions existed, the area was just far enough north of the best conditions to keep the most severe weather away. However, isolated wind damage and one tornado was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A survey of damage in the Cassopolis area by a NWS Survey team revealed that a EF1 tornado produced damage along a roughly four tenths of a mile path. Touchdown occurred on the southern outskirts of Cassopolis at a farm where a older two story barn was severely damaged with the entire second story of the barn being destroyed with damage thrown upward of 200 yards downstream (DI: SBO DOD 8). The tornado continued quickly northeast, passing across the northwestern part of the Ross Beatty Jr./Sr. High School property and impacting a detached two car garage, causing its total destruction (DI: SBO DOD: 6). Debris was thrown up to 500 yards northeast from the point of impact onto the Park Shore Golf Course, where several trees were snapped or uprooted. Maximum wind speeds with the tornado are estimated at 110 mph.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure moved across the northern Great Lakes, with a strong cold front trailing well south into Arkansas. A 50 to 60 knot low level jet aided in advecting in dewpoints greater than 60 degrees. 0-1km storm relative helicity values of 400 to 600 m2/s2 setup the perfect environment for individual thunderstorms to rapidly rotate with the lower values into far southern Lower Michigan. While favorable conditions existed, the area was just far enough north of the best conditions to keep the most severe weather away. However, isolated wind damage and one tornado was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported multiple trees were blown down on Red Arrow Highway. A tree was also down onto a local residence.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure moved across the northern Great Lakes, with a strong cold front trailing well south into Arkansas. A 50 to 60 knot low level jet aided in advecting in dewpoints greater than 60 degrees. 0-1km storm relative helicity values of 400 to 600 m2/s2 setup the perfect environment for individual thunderstorms to rapidly rotate with the lower values into far southern Lower Michigan. While favorable conditions existed, the area was just far enough north of the best conditions to keep the most severe weather away. However, isolated wind damage and one tornado was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter found tree limbs down. Damage to a building was reported by the spotter, but no details were given on the amount of damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deep low pressure moved across the northern Great Lakes, with a strong cold front trailing well south into Arkansas. A 50 to 60 knot low level jet aided in advecting in dewpoints greater than 60 degrees. 0-1km storm relative helicity values of 400 to 600 m2/s2 setup the perfect environment for individual thunderstorms to rapidly rotate with the lower values into far southern Lower Michigan. While favorable conditions existed, the area was just far enough north of the best conditions to keep the most severe weather away. However, isolated wind damage and one tornado was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported trees and power lines down throughout the entire county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense lake effect snow band set up over far southwest Lower Michigan during the morning hours of November 12th. Localized snowfall totals in excess of a foot were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy lake effect snow set up over the western half of Berrien County during the morning hours of November 12th. Snowfall totals ranged from a dusting in far eastern Berrien County to 17 inches in Saint Joseph. Many locations across western and northern portions of the country received more than a foot of snow. The accumulating snow and reduced visibilities with snowfall rates of 2 to 3 inches per hour at times created hazardous driving conditions across the area. Accidents and slide-offs were reported across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy lake effect snow impacted portions of southwest Lower Michigan on November 27th. Snowfall totals of 8 to 16 inches occurred in a narrow band across eastern Berrien County and far western Cass County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands set up over northern and eastern portions of the county during the late evening hours of November 26th and continued through the afternoon and early evening hours of November 27th. Snowfall totals ranged from less than an inch in far southwest Berrien County to between 8 and 16 inches across northern and eastern portions of the county. Reduced visibilities, with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at times, created hazardous driving conditions across the area. Accidents and slide-offs were reported across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A band of heavy lake effect snow impacted portions of southwest Lower Michigan on November 27th. Snowfall totals of 8 to 16 inches occurred in a narrow band across eastern Berrien County and far western Cass County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake effect snow bands set up over western Cass County during the evening hours of November 26th and continued through the afternoon and early evening hours of November 27th. Snowfall totals ranged from less than an inch in far eastern Cass County to between 6 and 12 inches across far western Cass County. Reduced visibilities, with snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour at times, created hazardous driving conditions across the area. Accidents and slide-offs were reported across the region.
